title: WISPedia -- the WISPs Encyclopedia
comment: References have been cited to the best of the contributors' knowledge. Any polite comments, additions or corrections, particularly regarding missing references or overlooked models, are warmly welcome. The long-term success of this project relies on continuous feedback and collaboration within the WISP research community
summary: The Weakly-Interacting Slim Particle encyclopedia (WISPedia) is a comprehensive reference work dedicated to the systematic compilation of theoretical models, Effective Field Theories, and frameworks involving Weakly Interacting Slim Particles (WISPs): a broad class of light, feebly coupled particles proposed in extensions of the Standard Model. In current times, where the number of models largely surpasses the number of new physics signals, this encyclopedia aims to provide a concise reference of their landscape. The goal is to provide a useful tool to the community to navigate among them. It does not aim to review all the models in detail, but to define their essential characteristics, and point the reader to useful and minimal material such as the original sources, review articles, tools and general compilations of bounds. Hence, the format of this reference resembles the direct style of a model encyclopedia of WISPs.

AI.tldr: WISPedia is a comprehensive encyclopedia compiling theoretical models, Effective Field Theories, and frameworks involving Weakly Interacting Slim Particles (WISPs), offering a navigational tool through the diverse landscape of these light, feebly coupled particles beyond the Standard Model.
AI.motivation: With the proliferation of models exceeding new physics signals, WISPedia addresses the need for a concise, accessible reference to organize and summarize WISP-related frameworks, directing researchers to essential resources.
AI.method: The encyclopedia systematically compiles key characteristics of WISP models, including original sources, reviews, and tools, using an encyclopedic format to provide minimal yet critical information without detailed reviews.
AI.result: It serves as a navigational resource for the community to efficiently explore WISP models, their theoretical foundations, and relevant literature without delving into exhaustive model-by-model analysis.
AI.conclusion: WISPedia fills a gap in organizing the expanding WISP framework landscape, aiding physicists in accessing essential information and connecting to foundational materials for further study.

title: Tuning the violins: dark sector phase transition models for the PTA signal
summary: First-order phase transitions in a dark sector have been invoked as an intriguing possibility to explain the observed stochastic gravitational wave background at nanohertz frequencies. Here we perform a comprehensive study of the generic requirements for such a phase transition to explain the observed signal while being consistent with all relevant constraints. We consider three broad model classes for strong first-order transitions, realised by an Abelian dark Higgs boson, a two-step phase transition involving two scalar singlets, and a conformal scalar field with loop-induced symmetry breaking, respectively. We discuss the tuning that is required to successfully explain the Pulsar Timing Array (PTA) signal in each of these cases, and highlight the underlying physical mechanisms. We conclude that all three scenarios can in principle describe the data, but that conformal models stand out as the most generic, and least tuned, explanation. Future observations by the PTA collaborations and collider experiments will be crucial to test the viability of this hypothesis, and to further narrow in on the model parameters, if the PTA signal is indeed due to a strong first-order phase transition.

AI.tldr: The paper explores three dark sector models to explain the observed gravitational wave background via first-order phase transitions, finding conformal models to be the most viable and least tuned.
AI.motivation: To determine if first-order phase transitions in dark sectors could account for the Pulsar Timing Array (PTA) gravitational wave signal while meeting observational constraints.
AI.method: Examined three model classes: Abelian dark Higgs, two-step transition with two singlets, and conformal scalar with loop symmetry breaking. Analyzed required tunings and physical mechanisms in each.
AI.result: All models can theoretically explain the signal, but conformal models are more generic and less tuned. Future PTA and collider data will help test and refine these models.
AI.conclusion: Conformal scalar models offer the most promising explanation for the PTA signal among the considered scenarios, pending observational confirmation.

title: Long-lived Left-Right signals at the FCC-ee
comment: 58 pages, 26 figures, up to 4 displaced vertices
summary: We give an extensive discussion of the displaced signals of heavy Majorana neutrino production at future electron-positron colliders operating at various proposed energies in the context of the Left-Right symmetric model. A comprehensive collection of channels is taken into account, ranging from those featuring $W$ and $W_R$ mediation to those induced by scalar mixing and gauge/scalar boson fusion, with connections to the mechanism of neutrino mass origin. The emerging signatures feature possibly multiple displaced heavy neutrinos that are in some cases accompanied by prompt activity and forward leptons. We derive the corresponding total production rates and differential distributions, which allow us to differentiate the channels and have analytical estimates of the signal yield. We then develop realistic estimates of the selection efficiencies using a dedicated vertexing algorithm which establishes the displaced decay positions and supplies a reliable proxy for reconstructing the full four-momenta of long-lived particles. This allows to determine the realistic reaches in the parameter space of the Left-Right symmetric model across the various channels, and we show that these can strongly surpass the LHC ones, demonstrating that future lepton colliders are sensitive to left-right symmetry breaking scales in the deep multi-TeV regime.

AI.tldr: The paper explores the displaced signals of heavy Majorana neutrinos produced at future electron-positron colliders operating at high energies, within the context of the Left-Right symmetric model. It evaluates various production channels, including $W$ and $W_R$ mediation, scalar mixing, and gauge/scalar boson fusion, and assesses the experimental viability using vertexing algorithms. The results show that these colliders can achieve superior sensitivity to left-right symmetry breaking scales beyond LHC capabilities, reaching multi-TeV regimes.
AI.motivation: To investigate the potential of future electron-positron colliders in probing the Left-Right symmetric model by analyzing heavy Majorana neutrino production signatures, which are inaccessible to current facilities like the LHC.
AI.method: The study comprehensively examines multiple production channels using theoretical calculations of production rates and differential distributions. It employs a dedicated vertexing algorithm to estimate selection efficiencies for detecting displaced decay vertices and reconstruct particle four-momenta.
AI.result: The derived production rates and experimental efficiencies demonstrate that future lepton colliders can achieve parameter space coverage surpassing the LHC, extending sensitivity to left-right symmetry breaking scales up to the multi-TeV range through displaced neutrino signals.
AI.conclusion: Future electron-positron colliders are uniquely positioned to explore the Left-Right symmetric model at unprecedented scales, with displaced heavy neutrino signatures providing a powerful probe of multi-TeV physics inaccessible to current hadron colliders.

title: Experimental Tests of Baryon and Lepton Number Conservation
comment: 48 pages, 8 figures; Invited review prepared for the Encyclopedia of Particle Physics
summary: Baryon number ($B$) conservation underlies the apparent stability of ordinary matter by forbidding the decay of nucleons, while lepton number ($L$) conservation plays a central role in the structure of lepton interactions and the possible origin of neutrino mass. In the Standard Model, $B$ and $L$ are accidental global symmetries rather than imposed fundamental principles. However, they are expected to be violated in many extensions of the theory, including frameworks of unification and processes in the early Universe. This review summarizes the status of experimental tests of $B$ and $L$ conservation and discusses them within a unified framework for interpreting current and future searches across different processes and experimental approaches, outlining historical and theoretical motivation, key physical processes, as well as their broader connections and complementarity to other searches.

AI.tldr: This paper reviews experimental tests of baryon and lepton number conservation, explores their violation in theories beyond the Standard Model, and provides a unified framework for interpreting current and future experiments.
AI.motivation: To evaluate the reliability of $B$ and $L$ conservation laws, crucial for particle stability and neutrino mass mechanisms, and their implications in unified theories and early Universe processes.
AI.method: Synthesizes experimental results from various search methods (nucleon decay, lepton-number violating processes), analyzes theoretical motivations (unification, baryogenesis), and connects them through a unified interpretive framework.
AI.result: Highlights the current bounds on $B$ and $L$ violation, emphasizes the complementarity of different experimental approaches, and identifies open questions linking particle physics and cosmology.
AI.conclusion: Stresses the necessity of continued experimental efforts and theoretical frameworks to probe $B$ and $L$ conservation, crucial for understanding new physics beyond the Standard Model and the Universe's evolution.

title: Systematic biases in parameter estimation on LISA binaries. II. The effect of excluding higher harmonics for spin-aligned, high-mass binaries
summary: The Laser Interferometer Space Antenna (LISA) will observe massive black hole binaries (MBHBs) with astoundingly high signal-to-noise ratio, leaving parameter estimation with these signals susceptible to seemingly small waveform errors. Of particular concern for MBHBs are errors due to neglected higher-order modes. We extend Yi et al. [arXiv:2502.12237] to examine errors due to neglected higher-order modes for MBHBs with nonzero (aligned) progenitor spins and total mass up to $10^8\,M_\odot$. For these very massive systems, there can be regions of parameter space in which the $(\ell, |m|)=(2,\,2)$ modes are no longer dominant with respect to higher-order ones. We find that the extent of systematic bias can change significantly when varying the progenitor spins of the binary. We also find that for the heaviest, and therefore shortest, MBHB signals, slight systematic errors can cause severe mis-inference of the sky localization parameters. We propose an improved likelihood optimization scheme with respect to previous work as a way to predict these effects in a computationally efficient manner.

AI.tldr: This paper examines how neglected higher-order modes in LISA observations of massive black hole binaries (MBHBs) affect parameter estimation, finding significant systematic biases dependent on progenitor spins and system mass. It proposes an improved likelihood optimization method to computationally predict these effects.
AI.motivation: The Laser Interferometer Space Antenna (LISA) will observe MBHBs with high signal-to-noise ratios, making parameter estimation sensitive to waveform errors from neglected higher-order modes. Previous studies did not consider nonzero progenitor spins or the highest mass systems, so this work aims to fill that gap.
AI.method: Extended the framework from Yi et al. to MBHBs with nonzero (aligned) spins and total masses up to 10^8 solar masses. Analyzed regions where higher-order modes exceed (2,2) dominance, quantified systematic biases from spin variations, and developed an efficient likelihood optimization scheme for sky localization errors.
AI.result: Found that progenitor spins significantly affect the extent of systematic bias. For very massive, short MBHB signals, small waveform errors can lead to severe sky localization misestimation. The proposed optimization scheme allows computationally efficient prediction of these effects.
AI.conclusion: Neglected higher-order modes pose critical challenges for LISA MBHB parameter estimation, especially for high-mass systems with spin. The improved likelihood method offers a practical tool to model these biases without prohibitive computational costs, advancing future waveform modeling accuracy.

title: An Interactive Metrics Dashboard for the Keck Observatory Archive
comment: 4 pages, 2 figures, Submitted to Proc. ADASS 2025
summary:
Since 2004, the Keck Observatory Archive (KOA) has operated as a NASA-funded collaboration between the NASA Exoplanet Science Institute ( NExScI) and the W.M. Keck Observatory. It ingests and serves all data acquired by the twin 10-meter Keck telescopes on Mauna Kea, Hawaii. In the past three years, KOA has begun a modernization program to replace the architecture and systems used since the archive's creation with a new modern Python-based infrastructure. This infrastructure will position KOA to respond to the rapid growth of new and complex data sets that will be acquired by new instruments now in development, and enable follow-up to identify the deluge of alerts of transient sources expected by new survey telescopes such as the Vera C. Rubin Observatory. Since 2022, KOA has ingested new data in near-real time, generally within one minute of creation, and has made them immediately accessible to observers through a dedicated web interface. The archive is now deploying a new, scalable, Python-based, VO-compliant query infrastructure built with the Plotly-Dash framework and R-tree indices to speed-up queries by a factor of 20.
  The project described here exploits the new query infrastructure to develop a dashboard that will return live metrics on the performance and growth of the archive. These metrics assess the current health of the archive and guide planning future hardware and software upgrades. This single dashboard will enable, for example, monitoring of real-time ingestion, as well as studying the long-term growth of the archive. Current methods of gathering metrics that have been in place since the archive opened will not support the archive as it continues to scale. These methods suffer from high latency, are not optimized for on-demand metrics, are scattered among various tools, and are cumbersome to use.

AI.tldr: The Keck Observatory Archive (KOA) has implemented a modern Python-based infrastructure to handle the growing volume and complexity of data, including real-time ingestion and a scalable query system. A new dashboard provides live metrics for monitoring and planning upgrades.
AI.motivation: The need to manage expanding and complex datasets from new instruments and respond to transient alerts from surveys like the Vera C. Rubin Observatory.
AI.method: Replacing legacy systems with Python-based infrastructure using Plotly-Dash and R-tree indices for efficient queries, enabling near-real-time data ingestion and a unified dashboard for metrics.
AI.result: Achieved a 20x speed-up in queries, real-time data availability within minutes, and a centralized tool for monitoring archive performance and growth.
AI.conclusion: The modernization ensures KOA can scale effectively, supporting future data challenges through improved real-time capabilities and optimized metrics monitoring.

title: A multi-event interface for next-to-leading order calculations in MadGraph5_aMC@NLO
summary: We detail the implementation of a multi-event interface for next-to-leading order (NLO) calculations in MadGraph5_aMC@NLO, allowing tree-level scattering amplitudes for multiple phase space points to be evaluated in each call to the integrated NLO differential cross section during event generation. Additionally, a multithreaded implementation based on this multi-event interface where tree-level amplitudes are evaluated in parallel across multiple CPU threads is presented for the Monte Carlo generation of quantum chromodynamical (QCD) events. Although this work primarily concerns the implemented code, some algorithmic changes involving the order of the application of phase-space cuts and calls to different scattering amplitudes are included. The codebase currently supports multi-threaded execution, but these changes pave the way for continued data parallelism in the form of on-CPU SIMD instructions or SIMT GPU offloading. A study in the runtime fraction spent in different diagrammatic contributions across various processes suggests that NLO QCD event generation are computationally dominated by tree-level scattering amplitude evaluations, which we show are perfectly suited for data parallelisation.

AI.tldr: The paper discusses enhancements to MadGraph5_aMC@NLO by implementing a multi-event interface and multithreading for NLO QCD event generation, improving computational efficiency through data parallelization of tree-level amplitude evaluations.
AI.motivation: To address computational bottlenecks in NLO QCD event generation, particularly the time-consuming evaluation of tree-level amplitudes during Monte Carlo simulations.
AI.method: 1. Developed a multi-event interface allowing batch evaluation of tree-level amplitudes across multiple phase space points per call. 2. Implemented multithreading to parallelize amplitude calculations across CPU threads. 3. Introduced algorithmic adjustments in phase-space cut application and amplitude calling order. 4. Laid groundwork for future CPU SIMD or GPU SIMT parallelism.
AI.result: Demonstrated that tree-level amplitude evaluations dominate NLO QCD computational costs, and showed these are highly amenable to data parallelization. The multi-threaded approach significantly reduces runtime by leveraging parallel processing.
AI.conclusion: The improvements enable faster NLO event generation, with further potential through advanced parallelization techniques like SIMD or GPU offloading. This advances high-energy physics simulations toward more efficient large-scale computations.

title: Optical Signatures of a Schwarzschild Black Hole in a Dehnen-Type Dark Matter Halo
summary: In this paper, the optical effects that occur near a Schwarzschild-like black hole (BH) with a Dehnen-type $(1,4,2)$ dark matter (DM) halo are explored. We first derive the photon sphere radius and obtain an analytical expression for the deflection angle in the weak-field regime by applying the Gauss-Bonnet theorem (GBT). For the strong-field regime, we perform ray-tracing calculations to examine the behavior of light trajectories and determine the corresponding number of orbits. We further compute the BH shadow and gravitational lensing in a plasma medium and provide constraints arising from the DM halo parameters. We also extend our analysis to weak gravitational lensing within plasma environments, considering both uniform and singular isothermal sphere (SIS) distributions. We find the analytical expressions for the deflection angle in the presence of plasma and examine the resulting effects on image magnification. The overall results highlight how DM halo properties and plasma characteristics jointly alter observable lensing signatures.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates optical effects around a Schwarzschild-like black hole embedded in a Dehnen-type dark matter halo, using analytical methods (Gauss-Bonnet theorem for weak deflection) and numerical ray-tracing for strong fields. It also examines plasma effects on gravitational lensing in both strong and weak regimes, showing how dark matter and plasma jointly influence observables like shadow size and magnification.
AI.motivation: To understand how dark matter halos and plasma environments modify gravitational lensing and black hole shadow observations, which are critical for testing alternative gravity theories and dark matter models.
AI.method: Analytical derivation of photon sphere and weak-field deflection using Gauss-Bonnet theorem; numerical ray-tracing for strong-field lensing and orbit count; plasma medium incorporation for both strong (shadow) and weak (lensing) scenarios with uniform/SIS distributions.
AI.result: Derived analytical expressions for plasma-affected deflection angles, quantified changes in shadow size and image magnification due to DM parameters and plasma density. Found joint influence of DM halo structure and plasma on observable lensing signatures.
AI.conclusion: Dark matter halo properties and plasma characteristics significantly alter gravitational lensing observables, underscoring the necessity to account for both in interpreting astrophysical observations of black hole systems.

title: Spectral response of SPHEREx
summary:
The Spectro Photometer for the History of the Universe, Epoch of Reionization, and Ices Explorer (SPHEREx) is conducting the first all-sky near infrared spectral survey spanning 0.75 to 5.0um with resolving power R~35 to 130. Linear variable filters mounted in front of six H2RG detectors produce a position dependent spectral response across the focal plane.
  This paper presents the ground-based spectral calibration of SPHEREx, including the cryogenic apparatus, optical configuration, measurement strategy, analysis pipeline, and resulting calibration products. Monochromatic wavelength scans are used to derive the spectral response function, band center, and resolving power for every pixel. Band centers are measured to better than 1nm for Bands 1 through 4 (0.75 to 3.82um) and better than 10nm for Bands 5 and 6 (3.82 to 5.0um). Out-of-band leakage is negligible for detectors above 1.64um and is present at the percent level below this wavelength. The resolving power is measured to within 5% and agrees with design expectations to within 10%.
  An on-sky spectrum of the Cat's Eye Nebula (NGC 6543) constructed from repeated observations provides in-flight verification and shows agreement between ground calibrated response and astrophysical emission features. Calibration products, including per-pixel band center and resolving power maps, are released through IPAC to support community use of SPHEREx data. The absolute spectral calibration will continue to improve through in-flight measurements, with further reductions in uncertainty expected for the longest-wavelength bands.

AI.tldr: The paper describes the ground-based spectral calibration of the SPHEREx mission, detailing its cryogenic apparatus, measurement strategies, and analysis pipelines. It achieves precise band center measurements and resolving power, validated by on-sky observations of NGC 6543. Calibration products are publicly released.
AI.motivation: To establish accurate spectral calibration for SPHEREx's all-sky survey, ensuring reliable data for cosmological studies and astrophysical analysis, particularly in measuring wavelength responses and resolving power across its detectors.
AI.method: Monochromatic wavelength scans were used to derive spectral response functions. Cryogenic ground tests and on-sky observations of the Cat's Eye Nebula validated results. Analysis pipelines generated per-pixel calibration maps.
AI.result: Band centers were measured precisely (better than ±1nm for shorter wavelengths, ±10nm for longer bands). Resolving power matches design expectations within 10%. On-sky data confirmed calibration accuracy. Calibration products are publicly available.
AI.conclusion: Ground calibration successfully meets SPHEREx's science requirements. Ongoing in-flight measurements will further refine the longest wavelength bands' calibrations, ensuring high-quality data for the astronomy community.

title: Study of the $J/ψ\to Λ\barΣ^0η$ reaction
summary: We study the isospin violating $J/ψ\to Λ\bar Σ^0 η$ reaction, recently measured by the BESIII collaboration, by looking at the dominant terms with $\bar Σ^0$ and a pair of pseudoscalar-baryon particles that form together an SU(3) singlet and can thus couple to the $J/ψ$. Next we allow these pairs to undergo final state interaction to produce the final $ηΛ$. We find that the relevant original channels are $\bar K N$ and $K Ξ$, and the non cancelation of terms involving charged and neutral particles, because of their different masses, is responsible for the reaction. With that mechanism we find a good agreement with the three experimental mass distributions.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes the isospin-violating J/ψ → ΛΣ̄⁰η reaction using SU(3) singlet states and final state interactions, explaining the observed mass distributions through non-cancelling terms from different meson masses.
AI.motivation: To understand the mechanism behind the recently measured BESIII collaboration's J/ψ decay reaction, which violates isospin symmetry.
AI.method: Examines dominant terms involving Σ̄⁰ and pseudoscalar-baryon pairs forming SU(3) singlets coupled to J/ψ. Allows these pairs to undergo final state interactions to produce ηΛ. Focuses on K̄N and KΞ channels, considering mass differences between charged/neutral particles.
AI.result: Found that non-cancellation of terms due to differing masses of charged/neutral particles explains the reaction. Achieved good agreement with experimental mass distributions.
AI.conclusion: The proposed SU(3) singlet channel mechanism with final state interactions successfully accounts for the observed isospin-violating J/ψ decay to ΛΣ̄⁰η.

title: Gravitational waves in a minimal gravitational SME
summary: In this work, we investigate the generation and propagation of gravitational waves within a minimal gravitational SME (Standard Model Extension). Starting from the modified graviton dispersion relation derived in the linearized gravity sector, we analyze the polarization properties of gravitational waves in the transverse-traceless tensor sector. We then construct the retarded Green function associated with the Lorentz-violating wave operator, explicitly verifying the causal structure of the theory and identifying the modified propagation speeds of the tensorial modes. In addition, we study the source-induced emission of gravitational waves from a binary black-hole system. We show that the gravitational waveform preserves the standard quadrupolar amplitude and polarization structure, while Lorentz-violating effects enter exclusively through a modification of the retarded time. As a result, the spatial components of the metric perturbation $h_{ij}(t,r)$ acquire a phase shift determined by the SME coefficients. Finally, we estimate phenomenological bounds to the model under consideration.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates the generation and propagation of gravitational waves in the minimal gravitational Standard Model Extension (SME), finding that Lorentz-violating effects modify the retarded time but preserve standard waveform properties, allowing for phenomenological bounds estimation.
AI.motivation: Explore how Lorentz violation in gravity affects gravitational wave observables, testing foundational aspects of relativity using astrophysical systems like binary black holes.
AI.method: Derive modified graviton dispersion relations, construct Lorentz-violating retarded Green functions, analyze polarization properties, simulate waveform emission from binary black holes, and calculate phase shifts induced by SME coefficients.
AI.result: Gravitational waveforms retain standard quadrupolar amplitude/polarization but exhibit SME-coefficient-dependent phase shifts in spatial metric components. Causal structure confirmed, and propagation speed modifications identified.
AI.conclusion: Lorentz violation in gravity leaves observable phase shifts in gravitational wave data, providing a testable framework for estimating SME model parameters using astrophysical observations.

title: NIAC project report: Solar system-scale VLBI to dramatically improve cosmological distance measurements
comment: 59 pages in big-ish font; NASA/NIAC Phase I study
summary:
We investigate the feasibility and scientific potential of the Cosmic Positioning System (CPS), a space mission concept enabling purely geometric distance measurements to sources at hundreds of megaparsecs by directly detecting electromagnetic wavefront curvature. CPS consists of a constellation of radio antennas distributed across the outer Solar System, operating on baselines of tens of astronomical units. By precisely timing the arrival of repeating fast radio bursts (FRBs), CPS infers source distances via trilateration -- analogous to global navigation satellite systems such as GPS but on cosmological scales.
  We show that CPS distance measurements could result in sub-percent constraints on the Hubble constant with even a handful of detections, whereas we predict that 10-100 FRB sources are likely visible. We evaluate dominant sources of uncertainty -- wavefront timing precision, interstellar refractive delays, spacecraft positional knowledge, and onboard clock stability -- finding these controllable at required levels using near-term technologies. Our nominal design employs five spacecraft with 8 m deployable antennas, 3-6 GHz receivers with sub-30 K system temperatures, and space-qualified atomic clocks similar to those on GPS satellites, supported by a ground network for ranging calibration and FRB alerts.
  Beyond cosmic expansion, CPS may enable frontier measurements in astrophysics and fundamental physics, including constraints on small-scale dark matter structure, microhertz gravitational waves (bridging pulsar timing arrays and LISA), and the outer Solar System mass distribution. The most significant viability issue concerns FRB properties at several-GHz frequencies; we recommend observational campaigns to characterize repeating FRBs in this band.

AI.tldr: The Cosmic Positioning System (CPS) is a proposed space mission that uses a network of radio antennas in the outer Solar System to measure distances to distant fast radio burst (FRB) sources via wavefront curvature detection and trilateration, offering sub-percent precision for the Hubble constant and enabling diverse astrophysical and fundamental physics studies.
AI.motivation: To address the need for precise geometric distance measurements at cosmological scales, achieving sub-percent constraints on the Hubble constant, and exploring fundamental physics topics like dark matter and gravitational waves through unique observations of FRBs and the Solar System.
AI.method: A constellation of 5 spacecraft with 8m antennas, operating at 3-6 GHz, using atomic clocks and precise timing of repeating FRB wavefronts to infer distances via trilateration. Uncertainties like timing precision, interstellar delays, and spacecraft positioning are managed with near-term technologies.
AI.result: CPS could achieve sub-percent Hubble constant constraints with 10-100 FRB sources, and facilitate studies of dark matter structures, microhertz gravitational waves, and Solar System mass distribution. Key challenges include characterizing FRBs at GHz frequencies.
AI.conclusion: CPS is technically feasible with existing technologies, offering transformative potential for cosmology and astrophysics, but requires observational campaigns to confirm FRB properties at relevant frequencies.

title: A Faint Progenitor System for the Faint Supernova 2024vjm
summary: Type Ia Supernovae (SNe Ia) are well known for their role as standardizable cosmological candles. Their uniformity is credited to their single origin as thermonuclear explosions of White dwarf (WD) stars. Nevertheless, some SNe Ia break this regularity. Prominently, the Iax subclass are less energetic and remarkably diverse, raising questions about their progenitor systems. While no progenitor system of a normal SN Ia has ever been detected, a luminous blue star was identified in pre-explosion images of the site of the bright SN Iax SN 2012Z, suggested to be a helium giant companion star acting as a mass donor to a WD SN progenitor. This is in line with models of weak mass accretion of a WD from a binary companion, producing an explosion that does not fully disrupt the star. However, these models fail to explain the properties of the faintest Type Iax explosions, suggesting either they originate from other WD binary systems, or even from massive progenitor stars. Here, we present the faint SN Iax SN 2024vjm - possibly the faintest supernova observed to date. Using a deep pre-explosion image taken by the recently launched Euclid space mission, we show that its progenitor system must be fainter than the helium giant SN Iax progenitor candidate of SN 2012Z, as well as that of the luminous red companion or remnant of the faint SN 2008ha, and may require a subdwarf helium star as a mass donor. The deep image also provides strong arguments against a massive star origin for this faint supernova. Our observations argue that SN 2024vjm is a WD explosion, but we find that remarkably faint SNe Iax fade more slowly than bright ones, i.e., they evolve in an opposite manner from the famous Phillips relation that makes regular SNe Ia cosmological candles.

AI.tldr: The analysis of the faint Type Iax supernova SN 2024vjm using Euclid imagery suggests it originates from a fainter progenitor system than previously observed Iax events, potentially involving a subdwarf helium star, and challenges the Phillips relation by displaying slower fading despite lower luminosity.
AI.motivation: To understand the origin of faint Type Iax supernovae and test the Phillips relation by studying the least luminous SN Iax observed.
AI.method: Analyzed pre-explosion images from the Euclid mission to detect the progenitor system and compared light curve fading rates of SN 2024vjm against conventional SNe Ia.
AI.result: SN 2024vjm's progenitor is fainter than known Iax progenitors, possibly a subdwarf helium star, and its slower fade contradicts the Phillips relation.
AI.conclusion: Faint Iax SNe may require alternative progenitor models beyond traditional WD+helium giant systems, and their behavior challenges the standard Phillips relation, impacting cosmological standard candles.

title: pMSSM versus complete models and the excellent prospects for top-squark discovery at HL-LHC
summary: LHC sparticle search limits are usually performed within the context of simplified models and subsequently interpreted within the 19 parameter phenomenological MSSM (pMSSM) as to how many models avoid search limits for a particular sparticle mass, often including WIMP dark matter constraints. We provide a critical discussion of this procedure and how it can go wrong due to the introduction of new prejudices. By ameliorating these conditions, one is pushed into the more plausible four extra parameter non-universal Higgs model (NUHM4). Implementing a decoupling/quasi-degeneracy solution to the SUSY flavor and CP problems leads to first/second generation sfermions in the tens-of-TeV range. In this case, the natural solutions typically contain top-squarks in the 1-2 TeV range which are accessible to high-lumi LHC (HL-LHC) searches. This search channel, along with higgsino and wino pair production, may allow a nearly complete scan of natural/plausible parameter space by HL-LHC.

AI.tldr: The paper critiques the standard method of interpreting LHC sparticle search limits within the pMSSM, suggesting improvements by using the NUHM4 model. It emphasizes that decoupling sfermions to high masses via a quasi-degenerate solution allows natural SUSY scenarios with accessible top-squarks and higgsinos/winos for HL-LHC searches.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to address biases introduced by interpreting LHC results in simplified models and the pMSSM, which may exclude viable SUSY parameter spaces. The authors aim to refine the analysis using the NUHM4 framework to better explore natural SUSY scenarios compatible with current constraints.
AI.method: The authors critically evaluate the standard approach of translating simplified model limits into the pMSSM, highlighting introduced prejudices. They then propose using the NUHM4 model with a decoupling/quasi-degeneracy setup for first/second generation sfermions (pushed to tens-of-TeV), enabling top-squark masses in the 1-2 TeV range. They analyze HL-LHC's potential to probe these scenarios through specific search channels.
AI.result: The key result is showing that with NUHM4 and proper decoupling conditions, natural SUSY regions become accessible to HL-LHC via top-squark, higgsino, and wino pair production searches. This could nearly fully explore plausible parameter spaces under these assumptions.
AI.conclusion: The conclusion is that reinterpreting SUSY searches within the NUHM4 framework, considering decoupled sfermions, makes HL-LHC capable of significantly narrowing or ruling out natural SUSY scenarios. This shifts focus from exclusion plots to comprehensive coverage of viable models.

title: Temperature of a spinning black hole via a simple derivation
summary: According to current theory a black hole has a nonzero temperature and thus radiates like any black body. This remarkable result was first shown by Hawking for a non-spinning black hole using general relativity to describe the black hole gravitational field and quantum field theory to describe the radiation. Since then the temperature of a spinning Kerr black hole has been calculated. There have also been many heuristic derivations for the temperature. In this work we derive the temperature of a Kerr spinning black hole using only classical general relativity and thermodynamics. It is very similar to Ref. 11 but is mathematically simpler and more self-contained. Our purpose is mainly pedagogical, to be more accessible to students and non-specialists with a knowledge of general relativity. We also call further attention to the expected explosive evaporation of small black holes, not yet observed, which would be an almost unique window into Planck scale physics. Finally, we discuss the idea that the cosmological dark matter, whose nature is currently unknown, may be composed of small primordial black hole remnants.

AI.tldr: The paper derives the temperature of a spinning Kerr black hole using classical general relativity and thermodynamics, offering a simpler, more accessible pedagogical approach. It also highlights the explosive evaporation of small black holes, potential insights into Planck scale physics, and the possibility of dark matter being primordial black hole remnants.
AI.motivation: To provide a simpler and more self-contained derivation of Kerr black hole temperature compared to existing methods, making the topic more accessible to students and non-specialists while emphasizing the importance of small black holes in exploring Planck scale physics and their role as dark matter candidates.
AI.method: Uses classical general relativity and thermodynamics to derive the temperature of a spinning Kerr black hole, streamlining the mathematical approach and following a similar methodology to Ref. 11 but with enhanced simplicity and clarity.

title: astromorph: Self-supervised machine learning pipeline for astronomical morphology analysis
summary: Modern telescopes generate increasingly large and diverse datasets, often consisting of complex and morphologically rich structures. To efficiently explore such data requires automated methods that can extract and organize physically meaningful information, ideally without the need for extensive manual interaction. We aim to provide a user-friendly implementation of a self-supervised machine learning framework to explore morphological properties of large datasets, based on the BYOL (Bootstrap Your Own Latents) method. By enabling the generation of meaningful image embeddings without manually labelled data, the framework will enable key tasks such as clustering, anomaly detection, and similarity based exploration. In contrast to existing BYOL implementations, astromorph accommodates data of varying dimensions and resolutions, including both single-channel FITS images and multi-channel spectral cubes. The package is built with usability in mind, offering streamlined pipeline scripts for ease of use as well as deeper customization options via PyTorch-based classes. To demonstrate the utility of astromorph, we apply it in two contrasting science cases representing different astronomical domains: images of protoplanetary disks observed with ALMA, and infrared dark clouds observed with Spitzer and Herschel. In both cases, we demonstrate how astromorph produces scientifically meaningful embeddings that capture morphological differences and similarities across large samples. astromorph enables users to apply a robust, label-free approach for uncovering morphological patterns in astronomical datasets. The successful application to two markedly different datasets suggest that the pipeline is broadly applicable across a wide range of imaging-rich astronomical context, providing a user friendly tool for advancing discovery in observational astronomy.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces astromorph, a user-friendly self-supervised machine learning framework based on BYOL, designed to analyze complex astronomical datasets without manual labels. It effectively clusters and explores morphological features in diverse datasets like protoplanetary disks and infrared dark clouds, showcasing broad applicability in observational astronomy.
AI.motivation: Modern telescopes produce vast, complex datasets requiring automated, label-free methods to extract meaningful information efficiently. Existing BYOL implementations lack flexibility for diverse astronomical data types, necessitating a specialized tool like astromorph.
AI.method: astromorph uses a self-supervised BYOL framework to generate image embeddings. It supports varied data dimensions and resolutions (FITS images, spectral cubes), providing both streamlined pipelines and customizable PyTorch classes for different user needs.
AI.result: Applied to ALMA protoplanetary disk images and Spitzer/Herschel infrared dark clouds, astromorph produced embeddings capturing morphological similarities/differences, demonstrating scientific utility and broad applicability across astronomical domains.
AI.conclusion: astromorph offers a robust, accessible tool for discovering morphological patterns in label-free astronomical data, enabling advancements in observational astronomy through automated analysis of diverse datasets.

title: Polarization Signatures of Inspiraling Hotspots around Kerr Black Holes
summary: Polarimetric interferometry is a powerful tool for probing both black hole accretion physics and the background spacetime. Current models aimed at explaining the observed multiwavelength flares in Sgr A* often assume hotspots moving on geodesic, Keplerian orbits. In many scenarios, though, a hotspot may instead follow an inspiraling trajectory, potentially transitioning into a plunge toward the black hole. In this work, we present a general framework to simulate the polarized emission from generic equatorial inspiraling hotspots in Kerr spacetime using a parametric four-velocity profile. This parametrization defines a continuous family of flows, ranging from Cunningham's disk model (fixed radius orbits outside the innermost stable circular orbit and plunging motion within the innermost stable circular orbit) to purely radial motion, thereby extending the standard assumptions. Within this framework, we show that inspiral motion produces a distinctive observational signature: a precessing, unwinding evolution of the polarimetric Stokes Q-U looping pattern, in sharp contrast with the closed Q-U loops associated with stable orbits at a fixed radius. We then explore how the morphology of these signatures depends on black hole spin, observer inclination, and magnetic-field configuration. The presented model can be applied to current and near-future interferometric observations of linear polarization, offering a new avenue to probe the physics of matter spiraling inward and the relativistic velocities of plunging plasma.

AI.tldr: This paper develops a framework to simulate polarized emission from inspiraling hotspots around a Kerr black hole, showing that inspiral motion produces a distinct precessing Stokes Q-U pattern useful for probing accretion physics and spacetime geometry.
AI.motivation: Current models assume hotspots on fixed geodesic orbits, but inspiraling trajectories (including plunge) may be more realistic. The goal is to extend these models and find observational signatures to test them.
AI.method: Parametrized four-velocity profiles model generic inspiraling trajectories in Kerr spacetime, covering Cunningham's disk model (stable orbits outside ISCO, plunging inside) to radial motion. Simulate polarized emission's Stokes Q-U loops.
AI.result: Inspiral causes unwinding and precessing Q-U loops, differing from closed loops of stable orbits. The pattern varies with black hole spin, observer inclination, and magnetic field configuration.
AI.conclusion: Providing a new tool for analyzing polarimetric interferometry data, this framework enhances our ability to study accretion dynamics and spacetime geometry near black holes like Sgr A*.

title: Towards a quantitative characterization of gravitational universality classes for order-4 random tensor models
summary: Random tensor models can be used as combinatorial devices to generate Euclidean dynamical triangulations. A physical continuum limit of dynamical triangulations requires a suitable generalization of the double-scaling limit of random matrices. This limit corresponds to a fixed point of a pregeometric Renormalization Group flow in which the tensor size $N$ serves as the Renormalization Group scale. We search for corresponding fixed points in order-4 random tensor models associated to dynamical triangulations in 4 dimensions. In a $O(N)^{\otimes 4}$ symmetric setting, we discuss the resulting phase portrait as a function of the regulator parameters. We optimize our results, identifying parameter values for which the results are minimally sensitive to parameter changes. We find three fixed-point candidates: only one of them is real across the entire parameter range, but only has two relevant directions. This should be contrasted with the university class of the Reuter fixed point in continuum quantum gravity, very likely characterized by three relevant directions. We conclude that simple combinatorial models of Euclidean triangulations and the Reuter fixed point most likely lie in different universality classes.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates the possibility of a physical continuum limit in 4D random tensor models by analyzing fixed points under Renormalization Group (RG) flow. It identifies three fixed-point candidates, with only one real and stable across parameters, but lacking enough relevant directions to match the Reuter fixed point in quantum gravity, suggesting different universality classes.
AI.motivation: To determine if random tensor models can provide a suitable continuum limit for 4D Euclidean dynamical triangulations similar to the double-scaling limit in random matrices, and to compare their universality class with the Reuter fixed point in quantum gravity.
AI.method: The authors analyze O(N)^⊗4 symmetric order-4 random tensor models, study the phase portrait under varying regulator parameters, and apply optimization to minimize parameter sensitivity. They search for RG fixed points and evaluate their relevance counts.
AI.result: Three fixed-point candidates are found: only one is real across all parameters but has only two relevant directions. This contrasts with the Reuter fixed point's three relevant directions, indicating different universality classes.
AI.conclusion: The simple 4D random tensor models likely belong to a different universality class from the Reuter fixed point in continuum quantum gravity due to differing numbers of relevant directions at their fixed points.

title: A new strategy for achieving multiple continuous cooling stages in an adiabatic demagnetization refrigerator
summary: This paper presents a three-stage continuous adiabatic demagnetization refrigerator (CADR) simultaneously providing cooling platforms at two different temperatures. Unlike conventional CADR with two continuous stages, this system does not require an extra continuous stage. It is achieved with carefully designed heat switch operations and stage sequences. This new strategy significantly reduces system complexity and mass. The detailed implementation of the two cooling platforms is described, and factors limiting system performance are analyzed. This CADR system has achieved a cooling power of 20 μW@1 K and 4 μW@300 mK simultaneously, offering a new design strategy for the development of CADR with multiple continuous stages.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a novel three-stage continuous adiabatic demagnetization refrigerator (CADR) that provides simultaneous cooling at 1 K and 300 mK without additional stages, reducing complexity and mass through optimized heat switch operations and stage sequences.
AI.motivation: To address the complexity and mass issues of conventional two-stage CADRs requiring extra stages for multiple cooling platforms, the authors sought a more efficient design for simultaneous low-temperature cooling.
AI.method: The authors designed a three-stage CADR system with carefully coordinated heat switch operations and stage sequences to create two cooling platforms at 1 K and 300 mK. They analyzed performance-limiting factors and implemented the system without adding extra stages.
AI.result: The system achieved simultaneous cooling powers of 20 μW@1 K and 4 μW@300 mK, demonstrating reduced complexity and mass compared to conventional designs.
AI.conclusion: This work proposes a new design strategy for multi-stage CADRs, enabling efficient simultaneous cooling at different temperatures and paving the way for advanced refrigeration systems in cryogenic applications.

title: Continuous Gravitational Waves from Supersoft X-ray Sources: Promising Targets for deci-Hz Detectors
comment: 14 pages, 9 figures, 1 table, comments are welcome
summary: Supersoft X-ray sources (SSSs) host white dwarfs (WDs) accreting at rates that sustain steady nuclear burning, driving rapid mass growth, radial contraction, and magnetic field amplification. Angular-momentum transfer from the accretion disk naturally spins up the WD, while the amplified internal magnetic field induces a non-axisymmetric deformation in presence of a misaligned rotation. Such WDs emits continuous gravitational waves (CGWs). We model the coupled evolutions of stellar mass, spin, and magnetic structure in accreting WDs in SSSs with \texttt{MESA}, and compute the resulting quadrupolar deformation with the Einstein-Maxwell solver \texttt{XNS}. We show that WDs in SSSs, particularly near the end ofthermal timescale mass transfer and close to the Chandrasekhar mass limit, produce CGWs predominantly in the deci-Hz band accessible to planned detectors such as DECIGO, BBO, Deci-Hz, ALIA, and LGWA, and are distinguishable from other Galactic CGW sources such as AM\,CVn systems, detached double WDs, and isolated WDs. Well-studied SSSs such as CAL~83 and RX~J0019+2156 can be detectable, enabling targeted CGW measurements that directly probe WD's internal magnetic fields and rotation, while blind searches can reveal hundreds of obscured SSSs otherwise missed in soft X-rays and map the hidden population of accreting, rapidly rotating, magnetized WDs in nearby galaxies. A CGW detection from WDs in SSSs could also identify potential pre-explosion Type~Ia progenitors.

AI.tldr: The study investigates supersoft X-ray sources hosting white dwarfs accreting at high rates, modeling their mass, spin, and magnetic field evolution. Using simulations, they predict these white dwarfs emit detectable gravitational waves in the deci-Hz range for future detectors and could be used to identify Type Ia supernova progenitors.
AI.motivation: To explore mechanisms generating gravitational waves (GWs) from accreting white dwarfs in supersoft X-ray sources (SSSs), assess their detectability with upcoming GW observatories, and uncover hidden populations of such systems beyond visible X-ray observations.
AI.method: Coupled numerical models using MESA for stellar structure/evolution, XNS for Einstein-Maxwell equations to calculate quadrupolar deformations. Considered scenarios near thermal timescale mass transfer termination and Chandrasekhar mass limit.
AI.result: SSS white dwarfs emit CGWs at deci-Hz frequencies detectable by DECIGO/BBO etc. Specific systems like CAL 83 may be detectable, offering probes of magnetic fields/internal structure. Blind searches could reveal hundreds of obscured systems mapping galactic distributions.
AI.conclusion: Gravitational wave observations of SSS white dwarfs can provide insights into their internal dynamics, reveal obscured progenitor systems for Type Ia supernovae, and distinguish these sources from other compact binary systems through GW signatures.

title: Constructing Dimension-8 SMEFT from Conserved Currents
summary: Effective Field Theories (EFTs) are the primary tool for interpreting precision collider data in the absence of new resonances. However, in the dimension-8 Standard Model Effective Field Theory (SMEFT), the utility of traditional algebraically minimal bases is fundamentally limited by kinematic mixing: multiple operators contribute to a single high-energy amplitude, creating degeneracies that obscure ultraviolet interpretations and complicate the application of theoretical constraints. We introduce a generative framework that resolves this by constructing operators directly from the conserved Noether currents of the Standard Model. The resulting Kinematically Diagonalized Current Basis (KDCB) ensures that each operator maps to a unique asymptotic energy scaling ($E^4$, $E^2$, $E^0$) in scattering amplitudes. This organization makes S-matrix positivity bounds manifest, enables a stable auxiliary-field formulation for Monte Carlo simulation, and provides direct diagnostics for universal versus non-universal ultraviolet completions through current decomposition. By rotating the operator space into physically interpretable sectors, the KDCB offers a transformative framework for global fits and a clear pathway from high-energy data to the structure of new physics.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces the Kinematically Diagonalized Current Basis (KDCB) for SMEFT, addressing kinematic mixing by organizing operators via Standard Model Noether currents to ensure unique energy scaling in amplitudes, improving UV interpretation and data analysis.
AI.motivation: Traditional SMEFT bases suffer from kinematic mixing causing degeneracies in high-energy amplitudes, which阻碍 precise UV model interpretation and complicate theoretical constraints applications.
AI.method: Develop a generative framework constructing operators from SM Noether currents to diagonalize the amplitude contributions, categorizing them by distinct E^4, E^2, E^0 energy scalings.
AI.result: KDCB successfully decouples mixing effects, enabling application of S-matrix positivity bounds, stable Monte Carlo simulations via auxiliary fields, and diagnostics区分universal/non-universal UV completions.
AI.conclusion: KDCB provides a physically transparent operator basis essential for precise collider data interpretation, global fits, and guiding new physics discovery through energy scaling patterns.

title: A Small Patch Hypothesis in Cosmology
summary: If our observable Universe is only a tiny region of a vastly larger and conformally older spacetime, then the usual formulations of the classical flatness and horizon problems of the Hot Big Bang can be reinterpreted as artifacts manifesting an observational selection effect; we occupy a small causal domain of a much larger causally-connected and possibly non-flat spacetime. A sufficiently large positive cosmological constant, $Λ$, sets the future asymptotic horizon scale of the observable Universe, $\sim$$Λ^{-1/2}$, thereby implying that the observable Universe may simply be a minute patch of a far larger pre-existing one, hereafter a Small Patch Hypothesis. Importantly, this observational bound is purely geometric; regardless of when the Universe is observed, the maximum accessible scale is finite and fixed by $Λ$, independent of inflationary dynamics, anthropic arguments, or assumptions about the global hosting spacetime. In this sense, inflation becomes one viable realization of the proposed Small Patch Hypothesis. Here, one particular non-inflationary alternative is considered for illustrative purposes in which a primordial spectrum grows logarithmically toward large scales, and in fact diverges at some finite $k_{c}$. If $k_{c}\ll Λ^{-1/2}$, then our local cosmic patch probes only the linear regime and appears exceptionally smooth. Over the comparatively narrow observable window, this power spectrum mimics a slightly red-tilted, inflation-like spectrum. Rather than introducing high-energy new fields, this perspective frames large-scale homogeneity, isotropy, Gaussianity, adiabaticity, and the observed thermodynamic Arrow of Time as possible consequences of restricted observational access to a much larger Universe in equilibrium, rather than signatures of a unique early-Universe mechanism. [abridged]

AI.tldr: The paper proposes that the observable Universe is a small region within a larger, older spacetime, suggesting that the flatness and horizon problems may arise from observational limitations rather than requiring inflation. A primordial power spectrum that diverges at large scales could explain the Universe's smoothness without inflation, attributing cosmic properties to limited observational access rather than early-universe mechanisms.
AI.motivation: To reinterpret the flatness and horizon problems as selection effects due to our limited observational scope, avoiding the need for inflation by considering a larger spacetime. The motivation is to explore alternatives to inflation by leveraging the Small Patch Hypothesis.
AI.method: Proposes the Small Patch Hypothesis where the observable universe is a tiny part of a larger spacetime with a cosmological constant setting the horizon. Considers a non-inflationary model with a logarithmically growing primordial spectrum that mimics inflation-like observations when cutoff at scales beyond the observable horizon.
AI.result: The model shows that a diverging power spectrum at large scales can explain the observed smoothness and spectrum similar to inflation. This suggests inflation is one of several possible realizations of the Small Patch Hypothesis, with cosmic properties arising from observational bounds rather than unique early-universe physics.
AI.conclusion: The interpretation shifts fundamental cosmic properties (homogeneity, Arrow of Time) as consequences of limited observation within a larger equilibrium spacetime, rather than specific early-universe mechanisms. This opens possibilities for alternative scenarios beyond inflationary models.

title: Talking with the Latents -- how to convert your LLM into an astronomer
summary: Recent advances in Large Language Models (LLMs) offer unique opportunities for scientific tasks, yet their ability to reason over complex numerical data remains largely unexplored. We propose a simple mechanism to introduce domain-specific physical knowledge into LLMs by fusing pre-trained latent physical features with a pre-trained language model. Our method employs a teacher-student knowledge distillation framework where a large LLM (teacher) generates synthetic question-answer supervision to transfer physical reasoning to a smaller LLM (student). The student is conditioned on latent physical features and trained via a lightweight adapter and Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA). We demonstrate that this approach, applied to models with 1B, 8B, and 32B parameters, enables effective reasoning over real scientific data. Our models substantially outperform strong baselines, such as Gemini 3 Pro, across multiple downstream tasks without task-specific fine-tuning. We show that the model combines latent information with general physical understanding to predict complex properties and can be "steered" by identifying physically meaningful directions in the latent space. This allows for explicit physical manipulation and natural language interpretation of latent structures. While our experiments focus on astrophysics, the framework is domain-agnostic and applicable to various scientific fields. Our main contribution is a general framework for using LLMs as interpretable interfaces to scientific latent spaces, enabling a single model to perform diverse tasks through natural language guidance. This work marks a step toward developing scientifically capable and useful LLMs.

AI.tldr: The paper presents a method to enhance LLMs with physical reasoning by fusing pre-trained latent physical features into LLMs via teachers-student knowledge distillation, demonstrating improved scientific task performance across model sizes.
AI.motivation: LLMs lack innate capability to handle complex numerical and physical reasoning tasks, requiring integration of domain-specific knowledge to enable scientific applications.
AI.method: Uses knowledge distillation where a large LLM (teacher) generates synthetic Q&A pairs to train a smaller student LLM. The student incorporates latent physics features through adapters/LoRA, allowing integration of physical knowledge without full fine-tuning.
AI.result: Models outperform Gemini 3 Pro and other baselines on astrophysics tasks. Demonstrates ability to interpret latent spaces for physical manipulation via language guidance.
AI.conclusion: Framework enables LLMs to act as interpretable interfaces for scientific latent spaces, applicable beyond astrophysics, advancing the development of domain-aware scientific LLMs.

title: A Comparative Study of the Supernova Remnant Cassiopeia A from 2013--2020 Deep [Fe II]+[Si I] Images
comment: 41 pages, 12 figures, accepted for publication in ApJ
summary: We present a comparative analysis of supernova remnant Cassiopeia A based on two deep, narrow-band images covering the [Fe II] 1.644um + [Si I] 1.645um lines obtained in 2013 and 2020 with the same instruments on the UKIRT 3.8m telescope. The identical setup and observing procedure allow for direct, accurate measurements of morphological and kinematic changes over a seven-year baseline. We identified 263 compact knots in the 2020 image and, through comparison with the 2013 catalog of Koo et al. 2018 (arXiv:1809.07935), classified them into quasi-stationary circumstellar knots and fast-moving knots (FMKs) of supernova ejecta. The FMKs show significant flux fluctuations, and many of those detected in 2013 are absent in the 2020 image. Proper-motion measurements derived from cross-correlation analysis indicate that most FMKs follow nearly ballistic expansion, whereas some, particularly those just beyond the eastern Fe-rich, X-ray emitting ejecta region, exhibit noticeable deceleration. The proper motions of the main ejecta shell were also measured and modeled as a uniformly expanding shell with a systemic motion, which reproduces the observed geometric and kinematic asymmetries of the remnant.

AI.tldr: The study uses two narrow-band images of Cassiopeia A from 2013 and 2020 to analyze morphological and kinematic changes. It identifies fast-moving knots and circumstellar knots, finds that many FMKs have disappeared or show deceleration, and models the main ejecta shell's expansion.
AI.motivation: To understand the dynamic evolution of Cassiopeia A by comparing long-term observations and assessing changes in its ejecta components and structural asymmetries.
AI.method: Obtained and compared narrow-band [Fe II] + [Si I] images from the UKIRT telescope over seven years. Identified 263 knots in 2020, classified them into FMKs and circumstellar knots. Used cross-correlation for proper-motion analysis and modeled ejecta shell expansion.
AI.result: Most FMKs show ballistic expansion, but some near the eastern Fe-rich region exhibit deceleration. Many FMKs detected in 2013 were missing in 2020. The main ejecta shell's uniform expansion model explains observed asymmetries.
AI.conclusion: Cassiopeia A's ejecta dynamics involve variable interactions (e.g., deceleration in specific regions), with evolutionary changes like disappearing knots over time.

title: Ward-Takahashi Identity in Denominator Regularization at One Loop
summary: Explicit analytic expressions for the electron self-energy and the vertex correction in quantum electrodynamics are derived at one loop using the recently proposed regularization scheme known as denominator regularization, assisted by its correspondence with dimensional regularization to determine the coefficient functions, which are a specific ingredient of this approach. We then show that the regularized amplitudes satisfy the Ward-Takahashi identity, thereby ensuring that gauge symmetry is preserved after regularization.

AI.method: Derive one-loop expressions using denominator regularization, cross-verify with dimensional regularization to determine coefficient functions, and verify Ward-Takahashi identity satisfaction.
AI.result: Successfully obtained regularized amplitudes that preserve the Ward-Takahashi identity, confirming preserved gauge symmetry.
AI.conclusion: Denominator regularization effectively maintains gauge invariance in QED calculations, offering a viable regularization method for quantum field theories.

title: Gravitational wave signatures from periodic orbits around a Schwarzschild-Bertotti-Robinson black hole
summary: In this paper, we investigate periodic bound orbits and gravitational wave (GW) emission in the Schwarzschild-Bertotti-Robinson (Schwarzschild-BR) spacetime-an exact electrovacuum solution describing a static black hole (BH) immersed in a uniform magnetic field. We explore how the background magnetic field qualitatively alters the BH's gravitational dynamics, affecting timelike geodesics such as the marginally bound orbit (MBO) and the innermost stable circular orbit (ISCO). We then analyze periodic bound orbits using the frequency ratio ${ω_{\varphi}}/{ω_{r}}$, which characterizes the orbits by their azimuthal and radial motions. Based on the numerical kludge method we further compute the gravitational waveforms emitted from periodic orbits around a supermassive Schwarzschild-BR BH. We show that the background magnetic field significantly changes orbital frequencies, resonance conditions, zoom-whirl structures, and the resulting waveforms. Finally, we examine the frequency spectra in the mHz range and the detectability of these GW signals by computing the characteristic strain via a discrete Fourier transform on the time-domain waveforms, comparing the results with the sensitivity curves of space-based GW detectors such as LISA, Taiji, and TianQin. Our results show that intrinsically magnetic fields modify spacetime and leave observable imprints on extreme mass-ratio inspiral GWs, which may be tested by future observations.

AI.tldr: This paper explores how a uniform magnetic field affects the gravitational dynamics around a Schwarzschild-BR black hole, examining orbital changes and gravitational wave (GW) signatures. It uses numerical methods to show that the magnetic field alters orbital parameters and GW emissions, which could be detectable by future space-based interferometers.
AI.motivation: To understand how background magnetic fields modify black hole spacetime and their observable effects on gravitational wave emissions, particularly for extreme mass-ratio inspirals detectable by missions like LISA.
AI.method: Analyzes timelike geodesics (MBO, ISCO) in Schwarzschild-BR spacetime, computes periodic orbits via frequency ratio ω_φ/ω_r, and uses the numerical kludge method to simulate GW waveforms. Fourier transforms evaluate detectability against LISA/Taiji/TianQin sensitivities.
AI.result: Magnetic fields significantly change orbital frequencies, resonance conditions, zoom-whirl patterns, and GW waveforms. Frequency spectra in mHz range show detectable characteristic strains by space-based detectors.
AI.conclusion: Intrinsic magnetic fields around black holes leave observable imprints on GWs, offering a testable prediction for future gravitational wave observations.

title: The Pollux European instrument concept for HWO: a high-resolution spectrograph and spectropolarimeter from the far-UV to the near-IR
comment: HWO2025 symposium held in Washington in July 2025
summary: Pollux is a high-resolution spectrograph and spectropolarimeter working from 100 nm to 1.8 microns proposed for HWO by a European consortium. Pollux will allow us to study stellar and (exo)planetary systems, as well as cosmic ecosystems. For example, Pollux will provide new insights on exoplanet formation and evolution, characterization of the atmospheres and magnetospheres of stars and planets, and star-planet interactions. It will also allow us to resolve narrow UV emission and absorption lines, enabling us to follow the baryon cycle over cosmic time -- from galaxies forming stars out of interstellar gas and grains, and planets forming in circumstellar disks, to the various forms of feedback into the interstellar and intergalactic medium -- and from active galactic nuclei. The most innovative characteristic of Pollux is its unique spectropolarimetric capability in the UV, which will open a new parameter space. Its very high spectral resolution (~70000 to ~100000) and stability over a very large wavelength range will also be a major asset. In this paper, we summarize the main scientific drivers of Pollux and present its current design, technological challenges, and the Pollux consortium organization.

It aims to study exoplanet formation, stellar/atmospheric characteristics, star-planet interactions, and the baryon cycle through cosmic time.
