AI.method: Employing a wide spectral range (100 nm to 1.8 µm) with resolutions of 70,000-100,000, advanced spectropolarimetric capabilities in UV, and stable observational systems to capture narrow lines and subtle polarization effects.
AI.result: Enabling breakthroughs in exoplanet atmosphere characterization, magnetic field studies, baryon cycle tracking through galaxy evolution stages, and overcoming limitations of current instruments in UV spectral analysis.
AI.conclusion: Pollux's innovative design represents a transformative tool for astrophysics, requiring interdisciplinary collaboration to finalize technical challenges and realize its scientific potential.

title: Transient Relativistic Iron Emission Line from an X-ray Flaring Supermassive Black Hole
summary: We report the discovery of the first transient relativistic iron Kα line in an Active Galactic Nucleus (AGN) J1047+5907. The line was detected 21.5 days (rest-frame) after an X-ray coronal flare observed in 2008 and it exhibits significant broadening consistent with relativistic reflection from the accretion disk in the vicinity of the central supermassive black hole (SMBH). The line has a width of ~300 eV, corresponding to a Keplerian velocity of 14,000 km s-1, at a distance of 5-41 light-days from the SMBH, strongly implying that the observed coronal flare triggered the emergence of the line. This event provides rare direct evidence of the response of the accretion disk to impulsive coronal illumination and offers a new method to probe the SMBH and disk physics. The relativistic modeling favors a broadened line produced by distant reflection from an accretion disk around a rapidly spinning black hole viewed at an intermediate inclination, consistent with other observations. Systematic monitoring of type 1 AGN following strong X-ray flares may open a new observational window into the innermost regions of AGN, enabling constraints on the physics of SMBH and its accretion disk at different radii that are otherwise challenging to access.

AI.tldr: The paper reports the discovery of a transient relativistic iron Kα line in AGN J1047+5907, linked to an X-ray flare. The line's broadening suggests rapid motion near a spinning SMBH, offering a new method to study disk dynamics and black hole properties.
AI.motivation: To investigate how accretion disks respond to sudden X-ray flares and to probe SMBH physics in regions inaccessible by other means.
AI.method: Detection and analysis of a transient iron Kα line post-X-ray flare using X-ray monitoring data. Relativistic models were applied to interpret the line's properties.
AI.result: The line's width (300 eV) corresponds to 14,000 km/s velocities, indicating origin near a rapidly spinning SMBH. The flare triggered the line's emergence, showing disk response to coronal illumination.
AI.conclusion: Systematic monitoring of AGN post-flare can reveal disk-SMBH interactions, providing new insights into accretion physics and black hole spin/inclination.

title: Entanglement suppression for $ΩΩ$ scattering
comment: 14 pages, Proceedings of the Southeast Asian Workshop on Nuclear and Hadron Physics (SEA-NHP 2025), 19th-21st August, 2025
summary: We study entanglement suppression in $s$-wave $ΩΩ$ scattering, where each baryon has spin $3/2$. By treating the $S$-matrix as a quantum operator acting on the spin states, we quantify its ability to generate entanglement and identify the conditions on the phase shifts of the spin channels that minimize entanglement generation in the system. In $ΩΩ$ scattering, only antisymmetric spin channels are allowed due to Fermi-Dirac statistics. Applying the entanglement-suppression framework to $ΩΩ$ scattering, we find two solutions for the phase shifts: one leading to a spin SU(4) symmetry and the other to a nonrelativistic conformal symmetry. We show that the solution associated with the nonrelativistic conformal symmetry originates from the specific structure of the Clebsch-Gordan coefficients in the $3/2 \otimes 3/2$ system.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates entanglement suppression in s-wave ΩΩ scattering by analyzing the S-matrix's effect on spin states, identifying phase shift conditions that minimize entanglement. It finds two symmetry-based solutions: SU(4) symmetry and nonrelativistic conformal symmetry, with the latter linked to Clebsch-Gordan coefficients in spin-3/2 systems.
AI.motivation: To understand how entanglement is suppressed in ΩΩ scattering under Fermi-Dirac statistics, focusing on the role of phase shifts and symmetries in minimizing entanglement generation between the spin states of these fermionic baryons.
AI.method: The authors treat the S-matrix as a quantum operator acting on spin states to quantify entanglement potential. They analyze allowed antisymmetric spin channels, derive conditions on phase shifts using the entanglement-suppression framework, and identify symmetries (SU(4), nonrelativistic conformal) that satisfy these conditions.
AI.result: Two viable phase shift solutions emerge: one requiring SU(4) symmetry and another nonrelativistic conformal symmetry. The conformal symmetry solution is specifically traceable to the Clebsch-Gordan coefficients' structure in 3/2⊗3/2 spin systems.
AI.conclusion: Entanglement suppression in ΩΩ scattering arises from specific symmetries in spin interactions. The nonrelativistic conformal symmetry's origin lies in the unique spin structure of Ω baryons, highlighting fundamental links between particle statistics, symmetries, and quantum information properties in high-energy systems.

title: Constraints on Interacting Early Dark Energy from a Modified Temperature-Redshift Relation and CMB Acoustic Scales
summary:
The Hubble tension, reflecting a persistent discrepancy between early- and late-time determinations of the Hubble constant, continues to motivate extensions of the standard cosmological model The Hubble tension motivates extensions of the standard cosmological model that modify pre-recombination physics. In this work we study an early dark energy scalar field coupled to radiation prior to recombination. The interaction leads to energy exchange between the two components and modifies the standard cosmic microwave background temperature redshift relation.
  We derive the modified temperature evolution from the background equations and interpret it in terms of effective photon non-conservation. We also study linear scalar perturbations in the tight-coupling regime relevant for cosmic microwave background acoustic physics. We show that the interaction affects the background evolution without introducing new dynamical degrees of freedom at the perturbation level.
  The dominant observational effect arises through a shift in the sound horizon at recombination, which modifies the angular acoustic scale. Using the Planck constraint on the acoustic scale we obtain a consistency bound on the coupling strength and show that deviations from the standard temperature redshift relation are tightly constrained.

AI.tldr: This paper explores an early dark energy scalar field coupled to radiation to address the Hubble tension by modifying pre-recombination physics. The interaction affects the cosmic microwave background (CMB) temperature redshift relation through effective photon non-conservation and shifts the sound horizon, enabling constraints on the coupling strength using Planck data.
AI.motivation: To resolve the Hubble tension, which is a discrepancy between early- and late-time measurements of the Hubble constant, by modifying pre-recombination physics through an interacting early dark energy component.
AI.method: Deriving modified temperature evolution from background equations, analyzing scalar perturbations in the tight-coupling regime, and examining effects on the CMB sound horizon and acoustic scale. Constraints on coupling strength are obtained using Planck data.
AI.result: The interaction modifies the CMB angular acoustic scale via a shifted sound horizon at recombination. Tight constraints on the coupling strength are derived from Planck's acoustic scale measurements, showing deviations from standard models are highly restricted.
AI.conclusion: Early dark energy-radiation interactions can contribute to resolving the Hubble tension but are severely limited by CMB constraints, indicating strict observational bounds on such models.

title: Reference File Updates Following the Application of New Geometric Distortion and Walk Corrections I: Overview
summary: The calibration of Cosmic Origins Spectrograph (COS) data is performed by the data processing pipeline known as CalCOS. CalCOS utilizes several reference files that store information required for data processing (e.g., dispersion solutions), and these reference files can be updated for the purpose of improving calibrated data products. In 2024 a major effort to improve the far-ultraviolet (FUV) geometric distortion, delta-geometric, and walk corrections was completed. Those three corrections occur early in the CalCOS workflow and shift photon events into the corrected reference frame ((XCORR, YCORR) coordinate system) in which subsequent calibration steps-and their reference files-are defined. This change necessitated the re-derivation of all "downstream" reference files in use at the time. Here we summarize the effort to create new versions of 56 reference files applicable to lifetime positions 1 through 6 and intended for use with the new geometric distortion, delta geometric, and walk corrections. The primary outcome of this work is improved wavelength and flux calibrations for COS FUV spectra.

AI.tldr: The paper discusses an improved calibration of Cosmic Origins Spectrograph (COS) FUV data through updated geometric distortion, delta-geometric, and walk corrections, requiring 56 new reference files and resulting in better wavelength and flux calibrations.
AI.motivation: To enhance the accuracy of COS FUV data processing by addressing geometric distortions and related corrections, which are critical for downstream calibration steps.
AI.method: Re-derive 56 reference files for lifetime positions 1-6 to align with new geometric distortion, delta-geometric, and walk corrections implemented in CalCOS. These corrections shift photon events into the corrected (XCORR, YCORR) coordinate system.
AI.result: Successful creation of updated reference files, leading to improved wavelength and flux calibrations for COS FUV spectra.
AI.conclusion: The recalibration effort significantly boosts data quality for future COS FUV analyses, ensuring consistency across all calibration steps dependent on the corrected coordinate system.

title: Mass-Radius Constraints for 2S 0918-549 from an RXTE Superexpansion Burst: A Direct Cooling-Tail Analysis
comment: 12 pages, 5 figures, 2 tables, published in ApJ
summary: Thermonuclear (Type I ) X-ray bursts from accreting neutron stars offer a means to determine neutron-star (NS) mass ($M$) and radius ($R$) and thereby probe the properties of matter at supranuclear density. A subset of these events, photospheric radius-expansion (PRE) bursts, provide a particularly powerful tool to constrain the neutron-star $M$ and $R$. Here, we apply the direct cooling-tail method to 2S~0918$-$549, using a rare superexpansion burst observed by \emph{RXTE}. We fit only the post-touchdown data within \(F/F_{\rm td}\in[0.6,0.95]\), employing modern atmosphere models (pure He and metal-enriched). The pure-He atmosphere yields a good description of the cooling tail (\(χ^{2}/ν=18.12/14\)), whereas metal-rich models fail; information-criterion tests (AIC/BIC) disfavor adding a free absorption edge in every time bin, indicating that heavy-element ashes are unnecessary. The joint fit gives a distance \(d=4.1-5.3\) kpc and mass-radius constraints \(M=1-2\,M_\odot\) and \(R=9.7-11.9\) km (99\% confidence). These results suggest that representative families of both gravity-bound and self-bound equations of state remain viable at the $1σ$ confidence level.

AI.tldr: The study uses a rare superexpansion burst from 2S 0918-549 observed by RXTE to constrain neutron star mass and radius via the cooling-tail method, favoring pure He atmospheres and supporting both gravity-bound and self-bound equation of state models.
AI.motivation: To determine neutron star mass and radius using photospheric radius-expansion bursts, particularly analyzing a rare superexpansion event to test equations of state under supranuclear density conditions.
AI.method: Applied the direct cooling-tail method to RXTE data of 2S 0918-549's superexpansion burst, fitting post-touchdown data with pure He and metal-enriched atmosphere models. Used statistical fits (χ²) and information criteria (AIC/BIC) to evaluate models.
AI.result: Pure He atmosphere provided a good fit (χ²/ν=18.12/14), while metal-rich models failed. Results yielded d=4.1-5.3 kpc, M=1-2 M⊙, and R=9.7-11.9 km (99% confidence), allowing viability of both gravity-bound and self-bound EOS models at 1σ.
AI.conclusion: The analysis supports the utility of PRE bursts for constraining NS parameters and shows that neither equation of state category can be ruled out at 1σ confidence, highlighting the need for further observations.

title: Constraints on invisible $B^{+}\to K^{+} X$ decays from the Belle II $B^{+} \to K^{+} ν\barν$ measurement
summary: Belle II measurement of the branching fraction for $B^{+} \to K^{+} ν\barν$ shows a $2.7σ$ excess over the Standard Model prediction and motivates new-physics explanations such as axion-like particles, Higgs-like scalars, or beyond Standard Model gauge bosons. A two-body decay \BKX with an invisible $X$ provides a natural candidate explanation. This work provides a comprehensive test of this hypothesis using Belle II's public model-agnostic likelihood. Posterior distributions are derived for the resonance mass $m_X$ and the branching fraction, and a modified frequentist upper-limit mass scan is performed. The data favor a resonance with mass $m_X = 2.1^{+0.2}_{-0.1}$ GeV and the product $\mathcal{B}(B^+\to K^+ X) \cdot \mathcal{P}_{X,\rm inv} = 9.2^{+1.8}_{-3.4} \cdot 10^{-6}$, where $\mathcal{P}_{X,\rm inv}$ is the probability that $X$ (and its decay products) are undetected. Bayes factors indicate a very strong preference for the Standard Model plus resonance over the Standard Model-only hypothesis. A frequentist likelihood-ratio test favors the Standard Model plus resonance hypothesis by $3.0σ$. A light invisible resonance plus the Standard Model therefore provides a compelling description of the Belle II data.

AI.tldr: The paper explores an observed 2.7σ excess in the $B^{+} 	o K^{+} ν\overline{ν}$ decay using Belle II data, proposing a light invisible resonance X within a two-body decay framework. Statistical analyses and likelihood tests strongly favor a resonance mass of 2.1 GeV and a branching fraction probability product of ~9.2e-6, offering a compelling Beyond Standard Model explanation.
AI.motivation: The motivation arises from the Belle II measurement showing a 2.7σ excess over Standard Model predictions for $B^{+} 	o K^{+} ν\overline{ν}$. This anomaly necessitates exploring Beyond Standard Model (BSM) physics, such as axion-like particles or new gauge bosons, which could manifest as an invisible resonance X in the decay process.
AI.method: The method involves analyzing Belle II's public model-agnostic likelihood to test the hypothesis of an invisible resonance X in the decay $B^+ \to K^+ X$. Bayesian posterior distributions for $m_X$ and the branching fraction-product are derived, and a frequentist upper-limit mass scan is conducted. Bayes factors and likelihood-ratio tests compare SM-only vs. SM+resonance models.
AI.result: Results indicate a preferred resonance mass $m_X = 2.1^{+0.2}_{-0.1}$ GeV and a branching fraction probability product of $9.2^{+1.8}_{-3.4} \times 10^{-6}$. Both Bayesian and frequentist tests show strong preference (3.0σ) for the SM+resonance hypothesis over the SM-only scenario.
AI.conclusion: A light invisible resonance coupled with the Standard Model provides a compelling BSM explanation for the observed Belle II anomaly. The findings suggest new physics involvement and motivate further experiments to validate and extend this resonance-based interpretation.

title: Dynamical Dark Energy Signatures from a New Transition $Om(z)$ Parametrization in Flat FLRW Cosmology
summary: We investigate a cosmic scenario using a new transition parameterization of the $Om(z)$ diagnostic, $Om(z) = \frac{z^l}{(1+z)^m}$, in the spatially flat Friedmann Lemaître Robertson-Walker (FLRW) framework. Using observational datasets such as Observational Hubble Data (OHD), Pantheon Plus (PP), and SH0ES, we analyze the evolution of the $Om(z)$ function to probe deviations from the standard $Λ$CDM model and constrain free parameter space {$H_0$, l, m } using Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) analysis with the emcee sampler. Our analysis reveals a clear transition in the slope of $Om(z)$ from negative to positive at transition redshift values $z_t \approx 1.41$, $0.65$, and $0.33$ for the OHD, OHD+PP, and OHD+PP$\&$SH0ES datasets, respectively. This behavior suggests a dynamical evolution of dark energy, indicating a transition from a quintessence-like phase to a phantom regime. From the combined OHD+PP$\&$SH0ES dataset, we obtain a best-fit value of the Hubble constant \( H_0 = 73.01 \pm 0.36 \, \mathrm{km\,s^{-1}\,Mpc^{-1}} \), which is consistent with the SH0ES calibration and supports the viability of our model. Additionally, our analysis indicates that the current age of the Universe is approximately $13 \sim 14$ Gyr from all available combinations of datasets, which is consistent with observational expectations. Further, we find that the deceleration-to-acceleration transition, which marks the beginning of cosmic acceleration, is inferred to occur within the redshift interval $z_t \in [0.5, 0.8]$, highlighting the emergence of dark energy as the dominant component in the Universe's recent expansion history. Our transition $Om(z)$ parameterization captured progressive cosmological changes and enabled seamless interpolation over cosmic epochs.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a new parameterization of the $Om(z)$ diagnostic to study cosmic expansion and dark energy evolution, finding a transition in the slope of $Om(z)$ suggesting a dynamical dark energy scenario from quintessence to phantom phases. MCMC analysis with observational data yields a best-fit $H_0 = 73.01 \pm 0.36$, aligning with SH0ES, and supports a deceleration-to-acceleration transition at $z_t \in [0.5, 0.8]$.
AI.motivation: To investigate deviations from the standard $\Lambda$CDM model and probe dynamical dark energy scenarios by analyzing the evolution of the $Om(z)$ function using updated observational datasets.
AI.method: Proposed a new transition parameterization $Om(z) = \frac{z^l}{(1+z)^m}$ within the flat FLRW framework. Conducted MCMC analysis with OHD, PP, and SH0ES datasets using the emcee sampler to constrain parameters $H_0$, $l$, and $m$, tracking $Om(z)$ slope transitions.
AI.result: Observed slope transitions in $Om(z)$ at $z_t \approx 1.41$, $0.65$, and $0.33$ for different datasets, indicating a quintessence-to-phantom dark energy evolution. Derived $H_0 = 73.01 \pm 0.36$ aligned with SH0ES and confirmed cosmic acceleration transition at $z_t \in [0.5, 0.8]$.
AI.conclusion: The transition $Om(z)$ parameterization effectively captures cosmological evolution, validates a dynamical dark energy model, and reconciles $H_0$ tension through observational consistency, emphasizing dark energy's role in recent cosmic expansion.

title: Operational Mass Measurement for Flyby Reconnaissance Missions of Potentially Hazardous Asteroid
comment: Submitted to the Journal of the Astronautical Sciences
summary: This study evaluates a technique for determining the mass of a potentially hazardous asteroid from a high-speed flyby in the context of a rapid reconnaissance planetary defense scenario. We consider a host spacecraft that dispenses a small CubeSat, which acts as a test-mass. Both spacecraft perform approach maneuvers to target their flyby locations, with the host targeting a close proximity flyby and the CubeSat targeting a distant flyby. By incorporating short-range intersatellite measurements between the host and the CubeSat, the mass measurement sensitivity is substantially improved. We evaluate a set of proposed host and CubeSat hardware options against the 2023 and 2025 Planetary Defense Conference hypothetical threats, as well as a hypothetical flyby of 2024 YR4. These scenarios differ predominantly in their flyby speeds, which span from 1.7 to 22 km/s. Based on these scenarios, we demonstrate that a typical radio-frequency intersatellite measurement is ineffective for asteroids with diameters relevant to planetary defense (i.e., 50 - 500 m). However, we find that augmenting the system with a laser-based intersatellite ranging system or a high-precision Doppler system can enable mass measurements of asteroids as small as 100 m across all cases, and as small as 50 m for the slower (< 8 km/s) cases. The results are very sensitive to the timing of the final maneuver, which is used to target the low-altitude flyby point. This presents an operational challenge for the smallest objects, where optical detection times are comparatively late and the optical navigation targeting knowledge converges too slowly.

AI.tldr: The study proposes a method to measure the mass of hazardous asteroids using a host spacecraft and a CubeSat during high-speed flybys, showing that laser or high-precision Doppler systems improve accuracy for asteroids as small as 50-100 m, but operational challenges exist for smaller objects and faster speeds.
AI.motivation: Assess techniques for rapidly determining asteroid mass during planetary defense missions, critical for understanding threat risks and designing mitigation strategies.
AI.method: A host spacecraft releases a CubeSat as a test-mass; both perform flybys at different distances while using intersatellite measurements (RF, laser, Doppler) to enhance mass sensitivity. Evaluated against real and hypothetical threats varying in flyby speed (1.7-22 km/s).
AI.result: Radio-frequency systems alone are ineffective for small asteroids (50-500 m). Laser or Doppler systems enable mass measurements down to 100m for all speeds and 50m for slower (<8 km/s) cases. Timing of final maneuvers significantly impacts accuracy, posing challenges for small asteroids and late optical detection.
AI.conclusion: Laser/Doppler-based intersatellite systems are essential for effective mass measurement in planetary defense scenarios, but operational constraints like maneuver timing and navigation precision require careful mission planning for fast/slow flybys and small asteroids.

title: Systematic Study of the Simultaneous Events Detected by GECAM
summary: GECAM is a constellation of all-sky monitors in hard X-ray and gamma-ray band primarily aimed at high energy transients such as gamma-ray bursts, soft gamma-ray repeaters, solar flares and terrestrial gamma-ray flashes. As GECAM has the highest temporal resolution (0.1~$μ$s) among instruments of its kind, it can identify the so-called simultaneous events (STE) that deposit signals in multiple detectors nearly at the same time (with a 0.3~$μ$s window). However, the properties and origin of STE have not yet been explored. In this work, we implemented, for the first time, a comprehensive analysis of the STE detected by GECAM, including their morphology, energy deposition, and the dependence on the geomagnetic coordinates. We find that these STE probably result from direct interactions between high-energy charged cosmic rays and satellite. These results demonstrate that GECAM can detect, identify, and characterize high-energy cosmic rays, making it a Micro Cosmic-Ray Observatory (MICRO) in low Earth orbit.

AI.tldr: GECAM, a hard X-ray/gamma-ray all-sky monitor constellation, was used to analyze simultaneous event (STE) characteristics, revealing their origin as cosmic ray interactions with the satellite. This highlights GECAM's role as a Micro Cosmic-Ray Observatory (MICRO).
AI.motivation: Understand the properties and origin of STEs detected by GECAM, which had not been previously explored due to lack of high temporal resolution instruments.
AI.method: Comprehensive analysis of STEs using GECAM's 0.1 μs temporal resolution, examining morphology, energy deposition, and geomagnetic coordinate dependencies.
AI.result: STE morphology and energy patterns indicate they arise from direct interactions of high-energy cosmic rays with the satellite.
AI.conclusion: GECAM demonstrates capability to detect and characterize high-energy cosmic rays, establishing its new role as a cosmic-ray observatory in low Earth orbit.

title: The S-wave topped meson
summary: Inspired by the recent observation of the near-threshold enhancement in top-quark pair production by CMS and ATLAS, we investigate the mass spectrum of S-wave topped meson which containing a single top quark, i.e., $t\bar{q}$, $t\bar{c}$, and $t\bar{b}$, in the framework of Bethe-Salpeter formalism. These states are expected to exhibit significantly enhanced lifetimes and correspondingly narrower decay widths compared to toponium, primarily because only a single top quark participates in the weak decay process. The numerical results indicate that the masses of topped mesons are close to the top-quark mass. For the $t\bar{b}$ states, the $1S$ state is approximately 5.08~GeV heavier than the top quark, while the $2S$, $3S$, and $4S$ states are about 5.37~GeV, 5.57~GeV, and 5.74~GeV heavier, respectively. For the $t\bar{c}$ states, the corresponding mass differences are 1.90~GeV, 2.23~GeV, 2.45~GeV, and 2.60~GeV. The possible production and decay properties are also analyzed, which could be measured in LHC experiments.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates the mass spectra and properties of S-wave topped mesons using the Bethe-Salpeter formalism, showing their masses are close to the top quark mass with distinct mass differences across states, and highlights their experimental detectability at the LHC.
AI.motivation: To explain the observed near-threshold enhancement in top-quark pair production by CMS and ATLAS, the authors aim to characterize topped mesons with potential longer lifetimes compared to toponium due to single-top weak decay dynamics.
AI.method: The Bethe-Salpeter formalism is applied to compute mass spectra for $t\bar{q}$, $t\bar{c}$, and $t\bar{b}$ meson states. Numerical calculations determine mass differences between these states and the top quark, varying by quark type and excitation level.
AI.result: Calculated mass differences relative to the top quark are 5.08-5.74 GeV for $t\bar{b}$ states and 1.90-2.60 GeV for $t\bar{c}$ states across S-wave excitations. States exhibit narrow decay widths and longer lifetimes.
AI.conclusion: The predicted topped meson properties, particularly their mass patterns and detectable decay characteristics, provide testable predictions for LHC experiments to validate the theoretical framework and explain the near-threshold production anomaly.

title: Revisiting critical orbits of test particles traveling in a black hole background
summary: This paper systematically revisits the critical orbits of test particles moving in various black hole backgrounds, including the Schwarzschild, Reissner-Nordström, Kerr, and Kerr-Newman spacetimes. We identify the critical orbit cases directly from the root structure of the radial equation, and provide explicit expressions relating the relevant parameters -- energy, angular momentum, and charge-to-mass ratio -- to the critical radius, as well as explicit expressions for the critical orbits in each scenario. Special attention is given to the relationship between the photon spheres, black hole shadows and the critical null geodesics. Extensive numerical results are also provided.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes critical orbits of test particles in different black hole spacetimes by examining the radial equation's roots, providing explicit parameter relations and expressions for critical radii, and explores connections between photon spheres, shadows, and null geodesics with numerical data.
AI.motivation: To systematically revisit and clarify the critical orbit structures in black hole backgrounds, addressing gaps in understanding photon spheres, shadows, and null geodesics through parameter relationships.
AI.method: Analyzing the root structure of the radial equation for Schwarzschild, Reissner-Nordström, Kerr, and Kerr-Newman spacetimes to derive explicit parameter expressions for critical orbits. Numerical simulations supplement analytical results.
AI.result: Explicit expressions linking energy, angular momentum, charge-to-mass ratio to critical radii in all spacetime types. Reveals relationships between photon spheres, black hole shadows, and critical null geodesics through both analysis and numerical results.
AI.conclusion: Critical orbits' parameter dependencies and their geometric implications (e.g., photon spheres and shadows) are systematically established, providing foundational tools for future studies in black hole dynamics and observational astronomy.

title: X-ray Timing and Spectral studies of bare AGN Mrk 110
comment: 16 pages, 8 figures, 2 tables, PASJ (under Review), received minor comments
summary: The origin of the soft X-ray excess below 2 keV in active galactic nuclei (AGNs) remains debated, with relativistic reflection from the inner accretion disk and warm Comptonization in an optically thick corona being the leading explanations. We investigate the timing and spectral properties of the Seyfert galaxy Mrk 110 using six XMM-Newton observations. A frequency-dependent lag analysis in the 7-9 $\times 10^{-5}$ Hz range reveals a soft X-ray lag of 889-3000s in the combined 2019 data, detected with a significance of 80%. The cross-correlation function analysis, supported by simulations, also detects lags of similar nature. Spectral modeling performed by adopting both proposed black hole masses in the literature for Mrk 110 confirms the presence of a warm corona in all observations, along with a weak relativistic reflection component and the reflection fraction remains low (Rf < 1). Interpreting the measured soft lag in terms of light travel time implies an emission radius 4.5 Rg for a supermassive black hole mass of $M = 1.4 \times 10^8$ solar mass , favoring a reflection scenario. However, if a lower mass of $M = 2 \times 10^7$ solar mass is adopted, the inferred radius increases, and both relativistic reflection and warm Comptonization can plausibly contribute to the observed soft lag. The warm corona radius appears larger in the high accretion state and smaller in a lower accretion state, although no trend can be established. The persistently low reflection fraction suggests an outflowing inner corona in Mrk 110, consistent with the recent detection of jet activity in this source.

AI.tldr: The study investigates Mrk 110's soft X-ray excess and uses XMM-Newton data to explore the role of warm corona vs. relativistic reflection. It finds evidence supporting a warm corona scenario for the soft lag, with the corona size varying with accretion state and weak relativistic reflection linked to jet activity.
AI.motivation: To clarify the origin of soft X-ray excess in AGNs between relativistic reflection and warm Comptonization in a corona. Existing black hole mass estimates for Mrk 110 require testing under both scenarios.
AI.method: Analysis of six XMM-Newton observations focusing on timing (frequency-dependent lags, cross-correlation) and spectral modeling. Examined lags at 7-9×10⁻⁵ Hz, tested two published black hole mass values, and applied spectral models (warm corona, reflection components).
AI.result: Significant soft lag detected (889-3000s, 80% significance), consistent with emission radii of 4.5 Rg for M=1.4e8 Msun. Low reflection fraction (Rf < 1) suggests corona outflow. Corona size anti-correlated with accretion state; jet activity detected aligns with this corona configuration.
AI.conclusion: Warm Comptonization from an extended corona likely dominates the soft X-ray excess. Relativistic reflection's role depends on black hole mass assumption. The corona's dynamic size and tie to jet activity highlight complex AGN accretion dynamics.

title: $S-P-D$ Mixing in Vector Quarkonia from the Salpeter Equation with Optimized Wave Function Representations
summary: This paper proposes a novel mechanism based on the instantaneous Bethe-Salpeter (Salpeter) equation for investigating wave function mixing in vector mesons such as $ψ(3770)$. Conventional theories typically treat $ψ(3770)$ as a $2S-1D$ mixed state; however, considering only tensor forces or relativistic corrections alone often leads to mixing angles that are too small and inconsistent with experimental data. Phenomenological $2S-1D$ mixing requires experimental data as input to determine the mixing angles, resulting in limited theoretical studies on states like $Υ(1D, 2D)$ in the absence of experimental data. To more accurately describe $S-D$ mixing and its relativistic effects, this paper systematically compares eight possible relativistic wave function representations ($\varphi_1$ to $\varphi_8$) by solving the Salpeter equation and calculates the mass spectra and dileptonic decay widths of charmonium and bottomonium. The study finds that the wave function representation $\varphi_2$ can simultaneously reproduce the experimental data of both charmonium and bottomonium well. Further analysis reveals that, in addition to $S-D$ mixing, the wave functions of vector mesons contain a non-negligible $P$-wave component, meaning they are $S-P-D$ mixed states. We predict the mixing angles for bottomonium $Υ(1D)$ and $Υ(2D)$ to be $(1.78^{+0.32}_{-0.25})^\circ$ and $(5.44^{+1.10}_{-0.76})^\circ$, with dileptonic decay widths of $2.29^{+0.86}_{-0.69}$ eV and $10.5^{+4.2}_{-3.1}$ eV, respectively.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a novel mechanism using the instantaneous Bethe-Salpeter equation to study S-D mixing in vector mesons like ψ(3770), finding that wave function representation φ₂ best fits experimental data for both charmonium and bottomonium. It also identifies a non-negligible P-wave component, leading to predicted mixing angles and decay widths for bottomonium states.
AI.motivation: Traditional methods for describing S-D mixing in vector mesons (e.g., ψ(3770)) using non-relativistic models with tensor forces alone fail to match experimental mixing angles. Additionally, existing approaches require experimental input for mixing angles, limiting theoretical predictions for unstudied states like Υ(1D, 2D).
AI.method: Systematic comparison of eight relativistic wave function parameterizations (φ₁-φ₈) via the Salpeter equation, calculating mass spectra and dileptonic decay widths for charmonium and bottomonium systems. Analyzes contributions from S-P-D wave mixing beyond conventional S-D mixing.
AI.result: Wave function φ₂ best reproduces experimental data for both charmonium and bottomonium. Vector meson wave functions include significant P-wave components, making them S-P-D mixed states. Predicted Υ(1D) mixing angle: 1.78±0.3°, decay width: 2.29±0.86 eV; Υ(2D): 5.44±1.1°, decay width: 10.5±4.2 eV.
AI.conclusion: Relativistic Bethe-Salpeter approaches provide a more accurate description of vector meson mixing by incorporating P-wave components, enabling theoretically grounded predictions for bottomonium states without requiring experimental input. This advances understanding of relativistic effects in hadron physics.

title: Thermodynamic Interpretation of the Kompanneets-Chernov-Kantowski-Sachs Solutions
summary: The spatially homogeneous perfect fluid solutions by Kompanneets-Chernov-Kantowski-Sachs are interpreted as a thermodynamic perfect fluid in isentropic evolution, namely, the isentropic limit of their non-homogeneous generalizations, the T-models. Some specific solutions that model a generic ideal gas are examined, and the associated thermodynamic variables are obtained. We show that the necessary macroscopic conditions for physical reality are fulfilled in wide spacetime domains. The field equations for a classical ideal gas are established, and the behavior of the solution is analyzed. The models fulfilling a relativistic $γ$-law are also examined, and the solutions for some particular cases are obtained.

AI.tldr: The paper examines spatially homogeneous perfect fluid solutions from the Kompanneets-Chernov-Kantowski-Sachs models as thermodynamic systems. It shows that these solutions satisfy physical reality conditions, derives field equations for ideal gases, and analyzes solutions under relativistic γ-law scenarios.
AI.motivation: To interpret existing fluid solutions as thermodynamic systems and validate their physical viability through macroscopic constraints. This bridges homogeneous models with broader non-homogeneous T-model generalizations in cosmology.
AI.method: Analysis of Kompanneets-Chernov-Kantowski-Sachs solutions as isentropic thermodynamic fluids. Derivation of field equations for classical ideal gases. Examination of specific solutions under relativistic γ-law conditions. Verification of physical reality criteria across spacetime domains.
AI.result: Solutions satisfy required physical conditions (energy conditions, thermodynamic stability) in extensive spacetime regions. Field equations for ideal gases and γ-law models yield analytically tractable solutions demonstrating valid cosmological behavior.
AI.conclusion: The models provide a physically viable framework for studying relativistic fluid dynamics in cosmology. They support further extensions to non-homogeneous scenarios and reinforce the applicability of thermodynamic approaches in understanding spacetime evolution.

title: In-flight calibration of the INTEGRAL/IBIS Compton mode: Application to the Crab Nebula polarization
comment: 15 pages, 19 figures. Accepted for publication in A&A
summary: The INTEGRAL satellite explored the gamma-ray sky since its launch on October 17, 2002, and until the end of its scientific operation on February 28, 2025. A large fraction of the available data is still largely untouched, due to the complexity of analysis. We describe the latest in-flight calibration of the Compton mode of the INTEGRAL/IBIS telescope, taking into account more than twenty years of data. The spectroscopy and polarization of the standard candle that is the Crab Nebula is analyzed in detail. We operate the IBIS telescope as a Coded mask Compton telescope, using the Crab Nebula to refine the calibration, as is usually done for high-energy instruments. We have determined the spectroscopic and polarimetric properties of the IBIS Compton mode and their evolution along the entire duration of the mission. In addition, the long-term evolution of the Crab Nebula's polarization has been successfully measured and compared with other high-energy experiments. We could estimate the energy dependence of the Crab Nebula polarization in four bands between 200 keV and 1 MeV. In particular, the detection of polarized emissions strictly above 400 keV makes it the highest energy measurement ever performed for the Crab Nebula. A Python library was also made publicly available to analyze processed data.

AI.tldr: The study presents advanced calibration and analysis of INTEGRAL/IBIS telescope data over 20+ years, focusing on the Crab Nebula's gamma-ray spectroscopy and polarization. It achieves the highest energy polarization measurement (above 400 keV) for the Crab Nebula and provides a public Python library for data analysis.
AI.motivation: To leverage underutilized INTEGRAL data due to analysis complexity, improve IBIS Compton mode calibration, and precisely measure the Crab Nebula's long-term properties for better understanding of high-energy astrophysical sources.
AI.method: Utilized 20+ years of INTEGRAL data, applied in-flight calibration using the Crab Nebula as a standard candle, operated IBIS in Coded mask Compton telescope mode, and analyzed polarization and spectroscopy across energy bands (200 keV to 1 MeV).
AI.result: Accurate determination of IBIS Compton mode's spectroscopic/polarimetric properties over the mission timeline, detection of polarization above 400 keV (highest energy for Crab), and creation of a public Python analysis tool.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates the capability of extended INTEGRAL data exploitation, validates the calibration method using a standard source, and establishes new benchmarks for high-energy polarization measurements, aiding future high-energy astrophysics research.

title: Elliptic Multiple Polylogarithms with Arbitrary Arguments in \textsc{GiNaC}
comment: 29 pages, 3 figures, discussed code to be released in GiNaC
summary: We present an algorithm for the numerical evaluation of elliptic multiple polylogarithms for arbitrary arguments and to arbitrary precision. The cornerstone of our approach is a procedure to obtain a convergent $q$-series representation of elliptic multiple polylogarithms. Its coefficients are expressed in terms of ordinary multiple polylogarithms, which can be evaluated efficiently using existing libraries. In a series of preparation steps the elliptic polylogarithms are mapped into a region where the $q$-series converges rapidly. We also present an implementation of our algorithm into the \texttt{GiNaC} framework. This release constitutes the first public package capable of evaluating elliptic multiple polylogarithms to high precision and for arbitrary values of the arguments.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces an algorithm for numerically evaluating elliptic multiple polylogarithms with arbitrary precision through a convergent q-series approach and efficient coefficient calculation using existing libraries. It is implemented in GiNaC as the first public tool for high-precision evaluation across all argument values.
AI.motivation: To enable high-precision numerical evaluation of elliptic multiple polylogarithms for any arguments, addressing existing limitations in computational tools.
AI.method: The algorithm uses convergent q-series representations mapped to regions of rapid convergence, with coefficients expressed via ordinary multiple polylogarithms evaluated using existing libraries. Integrated into GiNaC.
AI.result: Successfully implemented the first public package for precise evaluation of elliptic multiple polylogarithms across all argument values, providing a robust computational tool.
AI.conclusion: This work fills a gap in computational methods for elliptic polylogarithms, offering a widely applicable and efficient solution for high-precision calculations in relevant fields.

title: Resummed energy loss in extreme-mass-ratio scattering using critical orbits
comment: 12 pages, 8 figures + ancillary files attached and available at https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.18553926
summary: Motivated by recent efforts to bridge between weak-field and strong-field descriptions of black-hole binary dynamics, we develop a resummation scheme for post-Minkowskian radiative observables in extreme-mass-ratio scattering, augmented with post-Newtonian terms. Specifically, we derive universal interpolation formulas for the total energy emitted in gravitational waves out to infinity and down the event horizon of the large black hole, valid to leading order in the small mass ratio. We test our formulas using numerical results from direct calculations in black hole perturbation theory. The central idea of our approach is to utilize as a strong-field diagnostic the known form of divergence in the radiated energy along geodesics near the parameter-space separatrix between scattering and plunge. The dominant, logarithmic term of this divergence can be expressed in terms of instantaneous energy fluxes calculated along the unstable circular geodesics that form the separatrix, fluxes that we obtain using interpolation of highly accurate numerical data. The same idea could be applied to bound-orbit radiative observables via either unbound-to-bound mapping or a direct resummation of bound-orbit post-Newtonian expressions.

AI.tldr: The paper presents a resummation method combining post-Minkowskian and post-Newtonian approaches to calculate gravitational wave energy emission in extreme-mass-ratio scattering. It uses a divergence diagnostic near the separatrix between scattering and plunge orbits, validated with numerical data from perturbation theory.
AI.motivation: To bridge weak-field and strong-field descriptions of black hole binary dynamics, particularly in extreme mass ratio systems, by improving radiative observable calculations.
AI.method: Developed universal interpolation formulas for total radiated energy, incorporating post-Minkowskian and post-Newtonian terms. Utilized divergence analysis near the separatrix using unstable circular geodesic fluxes from interpolated numerical data.
AI.result: Derived formulas valid to leading order in mass ratio, tested against perturbation theory calculations. Showed applicability to bound orbits via mapping or direct resummation.
AI.conclusion: The resummation scheme effectively connects weak and strong field regimes in extreme mass ratio systems, offering a path to analyze both scattering and plunge dynamics through interpolation methods and separatrix diagnostics.

title: The supernova remnant J0450.4-7050 possesses a jets-shaped point-symmetric morphology
comment: It will be submitted in two days to allow for comments (including missing references)
summary: By examining recently published images in different wavelengths, I identify a point-symmetric morphology in the Large Magellanic Cloud core-collapse supernova (CCSN) remnant (CCSNR) J0450.4-7050 (SNR 0450-70.9; nicknamed Veliki), which I attribute to at least three pairs of energetic jets that participated in the explosion of the progenitor in the framework of the jittering jets explosion mechanism (JJEM). Two pairs of ears, a pair of blowouts in the north and south along the long axis of this SNR, and a pair of dents compose the point symmetric morphology. The fact that the symmetry axes of two pairs include pairs of opposite structural features in the inner ejecta implies that the shaping is by jets and not due to an interaction with an ambient material. While the JJEM predicts such morphologies, the competing neutrino-driven mechanism cannot account for point-symmetric morphologies. This study provides strong support for the claim that the JJEM is the primary CCSN explosion mechanism.

AI.tldr: The study identifies point-symmetric morphology in the CCSNR J0450.4-7050, attributed to three pairs of jets from the jittering jets explosion mechanism (JJEM), supporting its role over neutrino-driven mechanisms.
AI.motivation: To determine the explosion mechanism of core-collapse supernovae by analyzing the morphology of the remnant, which can differentiate between JJEM and neutrino-driven mechanisms.
AI.method: Analysis of recent multi-wavelength images of CCSNR J0450.4-7050 to identify structural features indicative of jet activity. The study examines symmetry, paired structural elements (ears, blowouts, dents), and their alignment to distinguish jet shaping from ambient interactions.
AI.result: Point-symmetric morphology with three pairs of jets-related features (ears, blowouts, dents) was observed, inconsistent with ambient interaction and consistent with JJEM predictions.
AI.conclusion: The JJEM is strongly supported as the primary CCSN explosion mechanism over neutrino-driven models due to the observed point-symmetric structure indicative of jet activity.

title: Cosmological signature and light Dark Matter in Dirac $L_μ-L_τ$ model
summary: We revisit an anomaly-free extension of the Standard Model (SM) $viz.$ gauged ${L_μ-L_τ}$ model in the Dirac framework, where the local $U(1)_{L_μ-L_τ}$ symmetry breaks and gives rise to a new gauge boson $Z'$ and corresponding gauge coupling $g_{μτ}$. Three additional heavy vector-like fermions, three light right-handed neutrinos and two heavy singlet scalars are added to complete the model framework for Dirac neutrinos. Another singlet vector-like fermion is added with a new gauge charge, which serves as a viable DM candidate, and the correct relic abundance is obtained via the resonance effect. The parameter space is considered after satisfying the current bounds on $M_{Z'}$ and the gauge coupling $g_{μτ}$. The influence of dark radiations coming from the additional light degrees of freedoms are studied in connection with the dark matter. After imposing all relevant theoretical and experimental constraints, the allowed parameter space is found to be highly restricted yet still accessible to ongoing and near-future experiments, rendering the scenario strongly predictive. Moreover, clear correlations among the relevant observables emerge throughout this study, making the model testable in current and future experimental searches.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a gauged $L_\mu - L_\tau$ model with a $Z'$ boson and additional particles, including a dark matter candidate, showing that the model remains experimentally testable despite stringent constraints.
AI.motivation: To explore an anomaly-free extension of the Standard Model that addresses dark matter and neutrino physics while avoiding theoretical inconsistencies, incorporating a $Z'$ boson and additional particles.
AI.method: Introduce a gauged $U(1)_{L_\mu - L_\tau}$ symmetry with vector-like fermions, right-handed neutrinos, and singlet scalars. Calculate relic abundance via resonance effects. Analyze parameter space under experimental and theoretical constraints.
AI.result: Parameter space is tightly constrained but still viable for current/future experiments. Correlations between observables emerge, enhancing testability.
AI.conclusion: The model offers a predictive framework for dark matter and neutrino physics, with testable predictions in upcoming experiments.

title: FPIC: a new Particle-In-Cell code for stationary and axisymmetric black-hole spacetimes
summary: In this paper we present a newly developed GRPIC code framework called FPIC, providing a detailed description of the Maxwell-equations solver, of the particle ``pushers'', and of the other algorithms that are needed in this approach. We describe in detail the code, which is written in Fortran and exploits parallel architectures using MPI directives both for the fields and particles. FPIC adopts spherical Kerr-Schild coordinates, which encode the overall spherical topology of the problem while remaining regular at the event horizon. The Maxwell equations are evolved using a finite-difference time-domain solver with a leapfrog scheme, while multiple particle ``pushers'' are implemented for the evolution of the particles. In addition to well-known algorithms, we introduce a novel hybrid method that dynamically switches between the most appropriate scheme based on the violation of the Hamiltonian energy. We first present results for neutral particles orbiting around black holes, both in the Schwarzschild and Kerr metrics, monitoring the evolution of the Hamiltonian error across different integration schemes. We apply our hybrid approach, showing that it is capable of achieving improved energy conservation at reduced computational cost. We apply FPIC to investigate the Wald solution, first in electrovacuum and subsequently in plasma-filled configurations. In the latter case, particles with negative energy at infinity are present inside the ergosphere, indicating that the Penrose process is active. Finally, we present the split-monopole solution in a plasma-filled environment and successfully reproduce the Blandford-Znajek luminosity, finding very good agreement with analytical predictions.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces FPIC, a new GRPIC code framework using spherical Kerr-Schild coordinates, featuring a hybrid particle pusher method for improved energy conservation and efficient computation in black hole astrophysics simulations.
AI.motivation: To develop a robust numerical framework capable of accurately simulating plasma dynamics in strong gravitational fields around black holes, addressing challenges like energy conservation and computational efficiency in relativistic scenarios.
AI.method: FPIC employs spherical Kerr-Schild coordinates, a leapfrog finite-difference time-domain solver for Maxwell's equations, and a novel hybrid particle pusher that switches between integration schemes based on Hamiltonian energy violation.
AI.result: Demonstrates improved energy conservation and reduced computational cost with the hybrid method. Successfully models the Wald solution in both electrovacuum and plasma-filled environments, identifies Penrose process activity via negative-energy particles, and replicates Blandford-Znajek luminosity in split-monopole simulations.
AI.conclusion: FPIC provides an efficient and accurate tool for relativistic plasma simulations around black holes, enabling exploration of energy extraction processes and validating key astrophysical theories through numerical agreement with analytical predictions.

title: The Too Visible QCD Axion
summary: Murayama proposed a GeV-scale axion theory where the up-quark mass term is generated dynamically by the QCD chiral condensate, spontaneously breaking a Peccei-Quinn symmetry. It predicts a too large mass splitting between neutral and charged pions. Trying to solve this problem we explore extensions. Despite some partial improvements, we identify a structural obstruction: the new Peccei-Quinn spurion breaks the accidental isospin symmetry of the chiral Lagrangian, leading to an enhanced higher-order operator. As a consequence, pion scatterings too are distorted. We also examine the limit in which the axion becomes light, finding that it is excluded by fifth-force constraints.

AI.tldr: The paper examines extensions of Murayama's GeV-scale axion theory to resolve excessive pion mass splitting but identifies a structural issue where new Peccei-Quinn spurions break isospin symmetry, causing pion scattering anomalies and fifth-force exclusion of light axions.
AI.motivation: To address the significant pion mass splitting issue in Murayama's original GeV-scale axion model and explore viable extensions while ensuring compatibility with experimental constraints.
AI.method: The authors analyze extended models of the original theory, investigate the impact of a new Peccei-Quinn spurion on isospin symmetry, and assess higher-order operators affecting pion interactions. They also examine the regime of light axions.
AI.result: Extensions partially improve pion mass splitting but introduce unwanted isospin-breaking effects in pion scattering. Light axions are ruled out due to fifth-force experiments.
AI.conclusion: The structural obstruction caused by the new spurion persistently limits model viability. Light axion scenarios are excluded, suggesting the need for alternative model frameworks.

title: Few-particle lepton bound states in variational approach
summary: The energy levels of the ground states of the three-particle and four-particle bound states of leptons in quantum electrodynamics are calculated. For the calculation, the variational method with Gaussian basis functions is used. The hyperfine structure of the spectrum is taken into account due to the pairwise spin-spin interaction of particles.

AI.tldr: The paper calculates the energy levels of three- and four-lepton bound states in quantum electrodynamics using a variational method with Gaussian basis functions, incorporating hyperfine interactions via pairwise spin-spin coupling.
AI.motivation: To accurately determine the energy spectra of multi-lepton systems while accounting for hyperfine effects essential for precision QED predictions.
AI.method: Variational method employing Gaussian basis functions, with explicit treatment of hyperfine interactions through pairwise spin-spin interactions in the QED framework.
AI.result: Computed ground state energy levels for three-particle and four-particle lepton bound states including hyperfine structure contributions.
AI.conclusion: The approach successfully models multi-lepton bound states, offering a robust method for studying QED effects in complex systems with precise hyperfine structure calculations.

title: Tensor states $ΥB_{c}^{\ast -}$ and $J/ψB_{c}^{\ast +}$
summary: Tensor states $\mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{T}}^{\mathrm{b}}=ΥB_{c}^{\ast -}$ and $\mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{T}}^{\mathrm{c}}=J/ψB_{c}^{\ast +}$ are explored using techniques of QCD sum rule method. These hadronic molecules, composed of only heavy quarks, have asymmetric quark contents $bb\overline{b} \overline{c}$ and $cc\overline{c}\overline{b}$, respectively. The masses $ m=(15864 \pm 85)~\mathrm{MeV} $ and $\widetilde{m}=(9870 \pm 82)~\mathrm{MeV} $ prove that these structures are unstable against dissociations to constituent mesons. Full widths of molecules $\mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{T}}^{ \mathrm{b}}$ and $\mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{T}}^{\mathrm{c}}$ are calculated by considering their dominant and subleading decay channels. The subleading channels are processes generated by annihilations of $\overline{b}b$ and $ \overline{c}c$ quarks. For the molecule $\mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{T}}^{\mathrm{b} }$ dominant decays are $\mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{T}}^{\mathrm{b}} \to ΥB_{c}^{\ast -}$ and $\mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{T}}^{\mathrm{b}} \to η_b B_{c}^{-}$, whereas subleading channels are transformations to $\mathcal{M}_{ \mathrm{T}}^{\mathrm{b}}\rightarrow B^{(\ast )-}\overline{D}^{(\ast )0}$ and $\overline{B}_{(s)}^{(\ast )0}D_{(s)}^{(\ast )-}$ mesons. In the case of $ \mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{T}}^{\mathrm{c}}$ we explore decays to $J/ψB_{c}^{\ast +}$, $η_{c}B_{c}^{+}$, $B^{(\ast)+}D^{(\ast )0}$ and $ B_{(s)}^{(\ast )0}D_{(s)}^{(\ast )+}$ mesons. Predictions $Γ[\mathcal{M} _{\mathrm{T}}^{\mathrm{b}}]=120^{+17}_{-12}~ \mathrm{MeV} $ and $Γ[ \mathcal{M}_{\mathrm{T}}^{\mathrm{c}}]=(71 \pm 9)~ \mathrm{MeV} $ for the widths of these molecules characterize them as relatively broad structures.

AI.tldr: The study explores tensor molecule states composed of heavy quarks using QCD sum rules, finding them unstable with broad decay widths.
AI.motivation: To investigate the existence and properties of exotic hadronic molecules with asymmetric heavy quark content, focusing on their stability and decay mechanisms.
AI.method: QCD sum rule method was applied to calculate masses and decay widths, analyzing dominant and subleading decay channels involving quark annihilations.
AI.result: Masses (15864±85 MeV and 9870±82 MeV) indicate instability against dissociation. Decay widths Γ of 120±17 MeV and 71±9 MeV show the molecules are broad.
AI.conclusion: These heavy quark molecules are confirmed as unstable, broad structures with characterized decay modes, contributing to understanding exotic hadrons.

title: Minimal Freeze-in Dark Matter: Reviving electroweak doublet dark matter with Boltzmann suppressed freeze-in
summary: Dark matter communicating with the Standard Model solely via electroweak interactions provides a compelling picture. However, thermal freeze-out of electroweak doublet dark matter is generically strongly excluded by direct detection. We show that SU(2)${}_L$ doublet fermion dark matter evades direct detection if its mass exceeds $10^{10}$ GeV. If the neutral Dirac fermion is split into a pseudo-Dirac pair (via high dimension operator) this limit can be relaxed to 300 GeV. Provided the dark matter mass is above the reheat temperature of the Universe, the production rate never exceeds the Hubble rate in cases of interest, thus the dark matter never thermalizes. We apply constraints from direct detection (e.g. LZ) and consider the discovery potential of Darwin. This scenario presents the most minimal model of freeze-in dark matter, and is both elegant and highly predictive.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes that SU(2)ₐ doublet fermion dark matter with masses above 10¹⁰ GeV (or ≥300 GeV with pseudo-Dirac splitting) can evade direct detection limits like LZ, offering a viable freeze-in scenario without thermalization.
AI.motivation: To address the strong exclusion of thermal freeze-out models for electroweak doublet dark matter from direct detection experiments, proposing a minimal freeze-in scenario with non-thermal production.
AI.method: Analyzes dark matter production via non-thermal freeze-in mechanism, considers pseudo-Dirac splitting via high dimension operators, applies direct detection constraints (LZ), and evaluates future prospects (Darwin).
AI.result: Shows that dark matter masses ≥10¹⁰ GeV (or ≥300 GeV with splitting) avoid detection limits. The model requires dark matter mass above the reheat temperature, ensuring non-thermalization.
AI.conclusion: Provides the most minimal freeze-in model for dark matter, maintaining elegance and predictive power while resolving direct detection exclusion issues for electroweak models.
